news_article:
NEW DELHI: The Yamuna continued to swell in the capital on Wednesday, crossing 207 metres at the Old Railway Bridge (ORB) at 1 pm, prompting fresh evacuations from low-lying neighbourhoods.

Earlier, at 8 am, the level at the ORB was 206.83 metres, already above the 206-metre evacuation mark that had been crossed on Tuesday. By 8 pm, on Wednesday, the level had risen further to 207.39 metres.

District administrations reported that more than 7,500 residents from the East, North, Southeast, Northeast, and Central districts had been moved to safety.

“Across five districts, more than 7,500 people have been evacuated. They have been shifted to relief camps at 25 locations, including tents, schools, etc.,” an official said. With water lapping at approach roads, the ORB remained closed to traffic throughout the day.

Officials attributed the steady rise to heavy discharges upstream. The Central Flood Control Room (CFCR) said the river received a discharge of 1.62 lakh cusecs from the Hathnikund Barrage and 1.38 lakh cusecs from the Wazirabad Barrage at 8 am.

“The rising water level is mostly due to the high volumes of water being released from the Wazirabad and Hathnikund barrages every hour. The forecast indicates a further increase in the water level,” a CFCR official said. The government added that it is monitoring flows round-the-clock from the Hathnikund, Wazirabad, and Okhla barrages.

During an inspection at the ITO barrage, Delhi Irrigation and Flood Control Minister Parvesh Verma urged calm, noting that recent desilting and channel-improvement work had expanded the river’s carrying capacity.

“In the past six months, steps have been taken by various departments to increase the river’s carrying capacity. Currently, the situation is under control, and even if the level rises by one or two metres more, water will not enter Delhi roads like it did in 2023,” he told reporters.

He added that “the Yamuna has not entered any authorised households,” and that rescue teams were operating in the floodplain. “Even if the level touches 209 metres, no authorised area will be flooded. We are expecting the water level to start reducing by evening,” he said.

The surge disrupted cremations at Nigambodh Ghat, the city’s oldest and busiest cremation ground, located along Ring Road behind the Red Fort.

With 42 platforms and an average daily load of 55–60 cremations, the facility halted new funerals on Wednesday afternoon after floodwaters entered the premises.

“Until about two hours ago, only rainwater had entered the premises. A wall approximately seven to eight feet high was damaged at the top, with about two feet collapsing, allowing Yamuna water to enter,” a management official at the ghat said. He noted that the ghat operated until 2:30 pm, after which no fresh cremations were taken up. Families arriving later were redirected to other cremation grounds.

The MCD said that rituals which had begun earlier in the morning were being completed.

Authorities appealed to residents in low-lying areas to heed evacuation advisories and make use of the facilities at the 25 relief sites. With inflows still elevated and the ORB closed, agencies said they would maintain heightened vigilance as the city awaited signs of the river receding.
summary:
The report details the worsening flood situation in New Delhi as the Yamuna River continued to rise on Wednesday, crossing 207 metres at the Old Railway Bridge (ORB) by 1 pm. This prompted new evacuations from low-lying areas. The river, which was already above the evacuation mark early in the morning (206.83 metres at 8 am), reached 207.39 metres by 8 pm.

More than 7,500 people across East, North, Southeast, Northeast, and Central Delhi districts were relocated to safety, accommodated in relief camps at 25 different sites, including tents and schools. The ORB, with water threatening the roads, remained closed to traffic throughout the day.

The steady increase in the Yamuna’s water level was attributed to heavy upstream discharges: 1.62 lakh cusecs from the Hathnikund Barrage and 1.38 lakh cusecs from the Wazirabad Barrage at 8 am, according to the Central Flood Control Room (CFCR). The situation was expected to get worse before improvement, with government agencies monitoring barrage inflows around the clock.

Delhi’s Irrigation and Flood Control Minister Parvesh Verma inspected the ITO barrage, assuring the public that recent desilting and river channel improvements had increased the Yamuna’s capacity. He stated the situation was "under control," asserting that even if waters rose one or two metres more, roads would not flood like in 2023. No authorized residential areas had been affected so far, and rescue operations were ongoing in the floodplain. Verma predicted water levels would soon start receding and maintained that even at 209 metres, authorized regions would not be flooded.

The floods disrupted operations at Nigambodh Ghat, Delhi’s largest and busiest cremation ground, which was forced to halt new cremations after Yamuna waters entered the premises by breaking through a damaged section of a boundary wall. Cremations already underway in the morning were allowed to finish, but families arriving later were sent to other facilities.

Authorities continued to urge residents of vulnerable areas to follow evacuation orders and use the relief camps, while maintaining a high state of readiness in anticipation of further developments as the city waited for signs that the river would recede.

news_article:
Getting to India’s tech capital just got a whole lot easier. Air India Express has launched new direct flights from Ahmedabad and Chandigarh to Bengaluru, opening the doors wider for both business and leisure travellers heading to the Silicon Valley of India.
“We’re now flying direct from Ahmedabad and Chandigarh to Bengaluru, our largest domestic hub with over 400 weekly flights to 34 cities. From Ahmedabad, enjoy convenient one-stop connections via Bengaluru to 26 domestic destinations and 3 international getaways. From Chandigarh, connect via Bengaluru to 23 destinations across South Asia,” an X post by the airline said.
The airline took off with its first Ahmedabad-Bengaluru and Chandigarh-Bengaluru flights on Monday, marking a significant boost to Bengaluru’s already growing aviation network. The Ahmedabad route will operate once daily for now, but is set to become twice-daily from September 16, news agency ANI reported. Chandigarh will enjoy two daily direct connections, ensuring morning and evening options for flyers.
And that’s not all - a new Bengaluru-Dehradun service is also scheduled to take off on September 15, further enhancing links between the Garden City and the Himalayan foothills.

The inaugural flight from Chandigarh was flagged off by Aloke Singh, Managing Director of Air India Express, who celebrated the occasion by presenting a commemorative boarding pass to the first passenger. The flight was operated using the airline’s new Boeing aircraft, VT-BXB.

“Our new routes from Ahmedabad, Chandigarh, and soon Dehradun to Bengaluru reflect our commitment to creating meaningful connections between state capitals and major metros. With thoughtfully curated fares including our cabin-bag only Xpress Lite fare, comfortable seats, hot meals onboard, and our unique 'Tales of India' aircraft liveries, we deliver a warm, distinctly Indian travel experience with every flight. This expansion is another step towards building our pan-India network serving leisure and business travellers with efficiency,” he said, as quoted by the agency.
summary:
Complete Summary
Air India Express has launched new direct flight routes connecting Ahmedabad and Chandigarh to Bengaluru, a move expected to make travel to India’s technology hub much more accessible for both business and leisure travelers. Announcing the expansion, the airline revealed that Bengaluru—already its largest domestic base with over 400 weekly flights to 34 cities—will now serve direct flights from Ahmedabad and Chandigarh.

From Ahmedabad, passengers can now access convenient one-stop connections via Bengaluru to 26 other domestic destinations and three international locations. The Ahmedabad-Bengaluru route is operating once daily initially, with plans for twice-daily service starting September 16. Passengers from Chandigarh will benefit from two daily direct flights—offering both morning and evening choices—to Bengaluru, providing one-stop connections to 23 South Asian destinations.

Further boosting connectivity, Air India Express will inaugurate a new Bengaluru-Dehradun service from September 15, reinforcing links between Bengaluru and northern India. The inaugural Chandigarh-Bengaluru flight was ceremonially flagged off by Air India Express Managing Director Aloke Singh, who presented a commemorative boarding pass to the first passenger. This new route uses the airline’s latest Boeing aircraft (VT-BXB).

Aloke Singh highlighted that the new services from Ahmedabad, Chandigarh, and soon Dehradun, are part of Air India Express’s commitment to connecting state capitals and major metropolitan hubs. He emphasized passenger-friendly fares, comfortable seating, hot meals, and aircraft with special ‘Tales of India’ liveries. The airline aims to provide a warm, Indian-inspired flying experience and to efficiently serve both leisure and business customers across its growing network.

news_article:
Bengaluru Suicide: After Bengaluru techie death, another woman dies of 'dowry harassment'
The Times of India

BENGALURU: Two separate cases of suicide by women allegedly due to dowry harassment have rocked Bengaluru this week.

Case 1: Poojashree
A 28-year-old woman named Poojashree, who was the mother of a 10-month-old child, died by suicide at her home in Bagalagunte on Tuesday. Police said she was subjected to repeated dowry demands and harassment by her husband, Nandish, and his mother. According to the complaint given by her mother, Poojashree was harassed both mentally and physically. She was also upset over Nandish's alleged extramarital affair.
Despite several attempts by her family to intervene, the abuse continued. The Bagalagunte police have registered a case against Nandish, his mother, and three others, arresting all under charges of dowry harassment and abetment of suicide.

Case 2: Shilpa
Earlier this week, a 27-year-old pregnant techie named P Shilpa was found dead at her BTM Layout residence. She was five months pregnant and was found hanging in her home. Police sources said there was no suicide note. She is survived by her elderly parents, two sisters, and a son.
Her mother, B Sharada, filed a complaint alleging that her husband Praveen and mother-in-law Shantavva harassed Shilpa for dowry and were responsible for her death. According to police, Praveen used to work as a software engineer but had recently been selling pani-puris after losing his job last year.
Police have detained both accused. Further investigation is ongoing.

Both cases highlight the continued prevalence of dowry-related violence and the urgent need for enforcement of anti-dowry laws. Despite strict legislation, incidents of dowry harassment and violence against women continue to be reported across the country.

Complete Summary
The article details two recent tragedies in Bengaluru related to dowry harassment and the resulting suicides of two women. The first case involves 28-year-old Poojashree, a mother of a 10-month-old, who died by suicide at her Bagalagunte home allegedly due to repeated dowry harassment and her husband's extramarital affair. According to her mother’s complaint, Poojashree faced both mental and physical abuse from her husband, Nandish, and her mother-in-law, especially after questioning Nandish's infidelity. Family efforts to intervene were unsuccessful. The police have arrested Nandish, his mother, and three others on charges of dowry harassment and abetment to suicide.

The second case, earlier in the same week, concerned a 27-year-old pregnant software engineer named P Shilpa, found hanging in her BTM Layout I Stage residence. There was no suicide note. Shilpa is survived by her parents, two sisters, and her son. Her mother, B Sharada, filed a complaint accusing Shilpa’s husband, Praveen, and his mother, Shantavva, of dowry harassment and contributing to her suicide. Police detained both accused. It was noted that Praveen had lost his software job last year and had since been selling pani-puri.

Both incidents are part of a broader, persistent issue in India concerning dowry-related violence despite laws in place to prevent such abuse.

news_article:
A Bengaluru woman is facing legal action after failing to inform the authorities before renting out her property to two foreign nationals. The incident came to light when officials from the Central Crime Branch (CCB) conducted a surprise raid at a residence in the Chudasandra area on August 26.
During the operation, two Ugandan women were found living in the house without valid documentation. The homeowner, identified as Ambuja, had allegedly not submitted Form-C, a mandatory document under the Foreigners Act that landlords must file with local police when accommodating foreign nationals, according to a report by the Deccan Herald. The form helps track the movement and residency of foreign visitors in India.

According to police, Ambuja failed to notify law enforcement about her tenants and did not complete the necessary registration procedures. Authorities have since registered a case against her under relevant sections of the Foreigners Act. She is currently absconding and efforts are underway to trace her, the report said.
The two Ugandan nationals have been taken into custody for questioning and are being investigated for visa violations or other possible offenses, it added.
City Police Commissioner Seemant Kumar Singh has once again urged Bengaluru residents to follow legal protocols when renting or leasing properties to foreign nationals. There are clear guidelines in place to ensure security and transparency, he said, as quoted in the report. Homeowners must submit Form-C and inform the jurisdictional police, otherwise, it can lead to legal consequences, he stated.
summary:
A Bengaluru homeowner, Ambuja, is facing legal action after she rented her property to two Ugandan women without informing local authorities or submitting the required Form-C, as mandated under the Foreigners Act. The incident was uncovered during a surprise raid by Central Crime Branch (CCB) officials at a residence in the Chudasandra area on August 26. The two Ugandan women were found living in the property without valid documentation.

According to the Deccan Herald report, Ambuja not only failed to notify the police about her tenants but also neglected to complete the necessary registration process that helps authorities track foreign visitors in India. As a result, a case has been registered against her under relevant sections of the Foreigners Act, and she is currently absconding with police efforts underway to locate her.

The two Ugandan nationals have been taken into custody for questioning and are being investigated for possible visa violations or other offenses. Bengaluru City Police Commissioner Seemant Kumar Singh reiterated the importance of adhering to legal protocols, emphasizing that landlords must notify police and submit Form-C when renting to foreigners. Failure to do so, he warned, carries legal penalties, as clear security guidelines exist for such situations.

news_article:
The GST Council on Wednesday night approved a two-slab GST structure, that of 5% and 18%, with a special rate of 40% on Sin and Luxury goods. The existing slabs of 28% and 12% will be done away with. This confirms multiple CNBC-TV18 newsbreaks with regards to the GST rate rationalisation, which were reported since Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Independence Day address on August 15.
These revised rates of GST will take effect from September 22.

Brokerage firm Nomura wrote in a note that the council bringing down GST for a number of staples and essential categories from 18% to 5%, is a meaningful reduction and will bring relief to stressed consumption, aid volume growth, and drive formalisation, as quite a few categories in India have a notable share from unorganised players.

Here are some of the key FMCG stocks that are likely to benefit from this GST rate rationalisation:


Colgate

100% of the company's portfolio benefits as toothpaste, toothbrush and personal wash go from 18% to 5%, while toothpowder goes from 12% to 5%.
Britannia

Nearly 85% of its portfolio will benefit as biscuits and cakes, which account for 78% of its overall sales, go from 18% to 5%, while Dairy, which is 5% of Britannia's overall sales, also moves to 5%.
Nestle India
As much as 67% of the overall sales of the company will benefit, as coffee and chocolates, which is nearly a third of its overall sales, drop to 5% from 18%, while noodles, milkmaid, also drop to 5%. Noodles and Milkmaid form 35% of the overall sales.
Dabur

Nearly half of its consolidated sales will benefit from this move as 28% sales for the company comes from toothpastes and hair oils and shampoos, moves to 5% from 18%. Along with this, 25% of its overall sales, which come from juices, digestives, ethical and toothpowder also moves from 12% to 5%.
Hindustan Unilever
37% of HUL's overall sales, which comes from saps, shampoos, toothpastes, health food drinks and coffee goes from 18% to 5%, while sauces, jams, mayonnaise, noodles, which account for nearly 3% of the overall sales, move from 12% to a 5% GST rate.
Bikaji Foods

Nearly 80% to 85% of the company's revenue comes from namkeens, bhujia and snack, where the GST rate goes down to 5% from 12%.
Bajaj Consumers

The GST on Hair Oil will also come down to 5% from 18% earlier, and nearly 83% of the company's overall sales come from hair oils.
Varun Beverages

Carbonated Beverages will now be taxed at a rate of 40% from 28% earlier. However, the earlier rate had a 12% compensation cess, which will now be done away with and merged into the overall rate structure. Therefore, Nomura does not see any significant impact for such companies.
Footwear Stocks

Stocks like Bata, Red Tape, Metro Brands and others could be beneficiaries as the GST goes down to 5% from 12% earlier on footwear up to ₹2,500, while those costing ₹2,500 and above will continue to have a 18% GST.
summary:
Complete Summary
The GST Council has approved a major structural change to India’s GST rate system, introducing two main slabs—5% and 18%—and a special 40% rate for Sin and Luxury goods. The previous slabs of 12% and 28% will be eliminated. This reform, aligning with predictions since Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Independence Day speech, will take effect on September 22.

Financial analysts, including brokerage firm Nomura, view the reduction of GST on essentials and staple goods from 18% to 5% as significant. This change is expected to offer relief for stressed consumption, support volume growth, and drive formalisation within the Indian market, as many fields have a considerable unorganised sector presence.

The article highlights key FMCG (Fast-Moving Consumer Goods) and related companies that stand to benefit:

Colgate: The entire company portfolio, including toothpaste, toothbrushes, and personal wash, now falls from 18% to 5%; toothpowder drops from 12% to 5%.

Britannia: 85% of sales (biscuits and cakes, which make up 78% of sales, and dairy, 5%) shift from 18% to 5%.

Nestle India: 67% of sales (coffee, chocolates, noodles, and Milkmaid) drop from 18% to 5%; noodles and Milkmaid alone account for 35% of sales.

Dabur: Half of all sales benefit—28% from oral care and personal care products, and 25% from juices, digestives, and ethical products—all see taxes cut to 5%.

Hindustan Unilever: 37% of sales (soaps, shampoos, toothpastes, health drinks, coffee) fall to 5%, while products like sauces, jams, mayonnaise, and noodles (3% of sales) drop from 12% to 5%.

Bikaji Foods: 80–85% of revenue (namkeens, bhujia, snacks) will now be at 5% instead of 12%.

Bajaj Consumers: Hair oil drops to 5% from 18%, representing about 83% of overall sales.

Varun Beverages: Carbonated beverages will now have a 40% tax rate instead of 28% plus a 12% cess; analysts expect no major impact, as the effective rate remains similar.

Footwear brands (Bata, Red Tape, Metro Brands, etc.): GST on footwear below ₹2,500 drops to 5% from 12%, with pricier footwear taxed at 18%.

The article concludes that GST rationalisation will provide widespread relief across segments, while goods considered luxurious or harmful remain highly taxed.

GST Council meeting LIVE

With the GST Council approving a complete overhaul of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) regime, the Congress on Thursday (September 4, 2025) termed it a "GST 1.5" and said time alone will tell whether it would stimulate private investment as well as ease the burden on MSMEs.

GST Council meeting LIVE

The Opposition party asserted that the wait for a "true GST 2.0" continues.

Congress president Mallikarjun Kharge said that for almost a decade, the party has been demanding simplification of GST.

“The Modi government changed ‘One Nation, One Tax’ to ‘One Nation, 9 Taxes’. It included tax slabs of 0%, 5%, 12%, 18%, 28% and special rates of 0.25%, 1.5%, 3% and 6%,” Mr. Kharge said.

“The Congress party had demanded GST 2.0 with a simple and rational tax system in its 2019 and 2024 manifestos. We had also demanded simplification of the complex compliances of GST, which had badly affected MSMEs and small businesses,” he said.

Congress general secretary in-charge communications Jairam Ramesh said that a key demand of the states made in the true spirit of cooperative federalism, namely the extension of compensation for another five years to fully protect their revenues, remains unaddressed.
 In fact, that demand assumes even greater importance now, he said.

The Indian National Congress has for long been advocating for a GST 2.0 that reduces the number of rates, cuts the rates on a large number of items of mass consumption, minimises evasion, mis-classification, and disputes, does away with inverted duty structure ' lower tax on output as compared to inputs ' eases the compliance burden on MSMEs, and expands GST coverage, Mr. Ramesh said on X.

He noted that Union Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman has made major announcements last evening after the meeting of the GST Council, which is a constitutional body.

"However, even before the GST Council meeting, the Prime Minister had already proclaimed the substance of its decisions in his Independence Day speech of August 15th, 2025. Is the GST Council to be reduced to a formality?" Mr. Ramesh said.

"Faced with a lack of buoyancy in private consumption, subdued rates of private investment, and endless classification disputes, the Union Finance Minister has finally recognised that GST 1.0 had reached a dead end. In fact, the very design of GST 1.0 was flawed and this had been pointed out by the INC way back in July 2017 itself, when the PM had made one of his typical U turns and decided to introduce GST," he said.

It was meant to be a Good and Simple Tax. It turned out to be a Growth Supressing Tax, Ramesh said.

Last evening's announcements have certainly made headlines since the Prime Minister had already laid down the pre-Diwali deadlines, he said.

Presumably the benefits of rate cuts will be passed on to consumers, he added.

"However, the wait for a true GST 2.0 continues. Whether this new GST 1.5, if it can be called that, stimulates private investment - especially in manufacturing - remains to be seen. Whether this will ease the burden on MSMEs, time alone will tell," Mr. Ramesh said.

Common use items from roti/paratha to hair oil, ice creams and TVs will cost less, while tax incidence on personal health and life insurance will be brought down to nil after the all-powerful GST Council on Wednesday approved a complete overhaul of the tangled Goods and Services Tax (GST) regime.

The GST Council approved limiting slabs to 5% and 18%, effective from September 22, the first day of Navaratri.

Almost all personal-use items and aspirational goods for the middle class, like AC, washing machines, will see rate cuts as the government looks to boost domestic spending and cushion the economic blow of the U.S. tariffs.

Premium paid for individual life insurance and health insurance (including family floater), policies too have been exempted from GST.

Earlier, such policies were subject to 18% GST.

Briefing reporters after a marathon day-long GST Council meeting, Union Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Wednesday (September 3, 2025) said all decisions were taken unanimously, with no disagreement with any state.

The panel approved simplifying the GST from the current four slabs - 5, 12, 18 and 28%, to a two-rate structure - 5 and 18%. A special 40% slab is also proposed for a select few items such as high-end cars, tobacco and cigarettes.

The new rates for all products, except pan masala, gutkha, cigarettes, chewing tobacco products like zarda, unmanufactured tobacco and bidi, will be effective September 22, she said.
summary:
Complete Summary
The article covers reactions to the GST Council’s recent overhaul of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) regime in India, moving to a simplified two-slab structure (5% and 18%) with a special 40% rate for Sin and Luxury goods, phasing out the previous 12% and 28% slabs. The changes will take effect from September 22. While the government touts these reforms as landmark, the opposition Congress party criticizes them, labeling the move as merely a "GST 1.5" (not a full “GST 2.0”) and expressing skepticism about its potential to stimulate private investment and reduce the burden on Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs).

Congress leaders, including party president Mallikarjun Kharge and general secretary Jairam Ramesh, reference nearly a decade of advocacy for GST simplification and highlight past government actions that resulted in a fragmented "One Nation, 9 Taxes" approach. They argue that true GST 2.0, promised in manifestos since 2019, should involve a rational, simple structure with reduced rates on mass-consumption items, minimized compliance burdens for MSMEs, and the removal of problematic features like inverted duty structures.

Ramesh also points out that demands for an extension of the GST compensation period to states, in the spirit of cooperative federalism, have not been met—emphasizing that the GST Council’s decisions appeared predetermined, since Prime Minister Modi had foreshadowed the reforms in his Independence Day speech before the actual council meeting.

The opposition contends that the original GST design was flawed (“Growth Suppressing Tax” rather than “Good and Simple Tax”), producing disputes, compliance headaches, and hindering private investment and consumption. They welcome rate cuts, such as GST exemptions for insurance policies and reductions on a range of consumer and aspirational items (from food staples to electronics and appliances), but maintain that the reform falls short of a true GST 2.0. The ultimate impact on investment, MSMEs, and consumers, they argue, remains uncertain.

The government, meanwhile, claims that all changes were unanimously agreed upon and highlight the likely benefit to households and the middle class from reduced rates on many goods and services.

news_article:
The major reform announced by the Goods and Services Tax (GST) Council has eliminated the 12% and 28% slabs, leaving just two main rates – 5% and 18% – which together account for 74% of GST revenue. There is also a special 40% slab for luxury and sin goods.

The move has been described as a long overdue correction by the BJP-led central government, who say this completes the process of simplification and rationalisation started with GST's introduction in 2017. However, the Congress and several opposition parties have responded with skepticism and concern.

Congress president Mallikarjun Kharge, taking a jab at the government, said: “The Modi government changed ‘One Nation, One Tax’ to ‘One Nation, Nine Taxes’.” Senior leader P Chidambaram said, “The GST design adopted in 2017 ought not to have been introduced at all. The multiple rates, cesses and surcharges made life difficult for businesses and the common man. The latest reforms should have come eight years ago.” Chidambaram argued that the reforms are being implemented now only because of rising household debt and slowing growth, as well as the political imperative of state and national elections due next year.

Opposition leaders also questioned whether states would lose revenue. Shiv Sena (UBT) leader Priyanka Chaturvedi and Tamil Nadu finance minister Thangam Thennarasu (DMK) said they welcomed corrections that would ease the burden on common people but are concerned over compensation to states. Other opposition parties, including the Trinamool Congress, quipped that the move should be called “GST 1.5”, not “GST 2.0”.

Trinamool Congress MP Mahua Moitra said that the removal of GST on insurance premiums was done after consistent demands by West Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee and others. Moitra said, “Full credit goes to her and other opposition leaders who persisted with the demand.”

In contrast, the government and NDA allies continued to defend the overhaul. Andhra Pradesh chief minister Chandrababu Naidu called it “growth- and jobs-oriented” and Janata Dal (United) finance spokesperson Rajiv Ranjan said the reform would benefit farmers, small businesses and women. Union finance ministry officials highlighted that the two-rate structure was based on sustained revenue analysis and would support critical areas of education and health.

Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman told reporters that the GST Council’s decisions were based on months of consultations with all states and denied that political concerns or US tariffs had anything to do with the timing.

The Congress, however, maintained that issues like clarity on state compensation, simplified compliances, tackling evasion, and protection for MSMEs were unresolved, and said the party would continue to push for a “true GST 2.0”.
summary:
The article discusses the reactions of major political parties and leaders to the GST Council’s recent overhaul of India’s tax slab structure. The Council has eliminated the 12% and 28% brackets, retaining only the 5% and 18% rates (which make up 74% of GST revenue), and set a special 40% “sin” tax for certain luxury goods. While the BJP-led central government presents the reforms as a long-overdue correction to simplify GST and stimulate the economy, the Congress party and several opposition groups express skepticism and mixed feelings.

Congress President Mallikarjun Kharge accuses the government of distorting the "one nation, one tax" principle, resulting in “one nation, nine taxes.” Senior leader P Chidambaram claims the prevailing GST design and past rate system “ought not to have been introduced,” and criticizes the government for making reforms “eight years too late.” He and other Congress voices suggest that the changes were a response to sluggish growth, rising household debt, and election cycles—implying that reforms were motivated by political expediency rather than public benefit.

Other opposition members, such as Shiv Sena’s Priyanka Chaturvedi and the DMK’s Thangam Thennarasu, cautiously welcome the correction but highlight concerns such as a potential loss of revenue for states. Opposition parties call the reform "GST 1.5," stating that only time will reveal whether it will truly stimulate investment and relieve pressure on MSMEs.

Trinamool Congress MP Mahua Moitra notes that the removal of GST on insurance premiums follows demands from various leaders, including Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee, and seeks to minimize BJP’s claims of credit.

In contrast, government spokespersons and allies such as the Janata Dal United and Andhra Pradesh’s Chandrababu Naidu praise the reforms as “growth-oriented” and “pro-poor.” The Centre and Union Finance Ministry argue that retaining two main GST rates is based on revenue data, and say the overhaul is intended to benefit broad economic interests and provide relief to the middle class and sectors like education, health, and farming. The government denies political motives—such as U.S. tariffs or impending elections—play any role.

The article concludes by noting these reforms are supported by some NDA allies, with opposition scrutiny focused on implementation, state compensation, and whether real relief will reach ordinary Indians.

news_article:
Under the next-generation reforms to the Goods and Services Tax (GST) regime, cleared by the GST Council Wednesday, some of India’s best selling cars and motorcycles will see a reduction in tax incidence, which is expected to boost consumption in a sector which is seen as a crucial marker of the growth in the country’s economy.

The ‘GST 2,0’ reforms include a broad two-slab structure of 5 per cent and 18 per cent with a demerit rate of 40 per cent rate only for super luxury, sin and demerit goods. The aim is to lower tax burden on common people with sweeping rate cuts and reduction in GST slabs, ease blocked working capital, and facilitate ease of doing business with automated refunds and registration process.

Small cars, mini SUVs gain; bigger cars largely neutral

Small cars with engine capacity not exceeding 1200 cc (petrol) and 1500 cc (diesel) and with length not over 4 metres will now be in the 18 per cent slab, as opposed to the earlier 28 per cent slab. This means that popular hatchbacks like the Maruti Suzuki Wagon R, and mini SUVs like the Maruti Suzuki Fronx, Tata Punch and Skoda Kylaq will now be taxed at a lower rate. There is also going to be tax relief for motorcycles with engine capacity less than 350 cc and all automotive parts that will now be taxed at 18 per cent.

For petrol cars that have an engine capacity of more than 1200 cc, and diesel cars with an engine capacity of more than 1500 cc, and a length of over 4 metres, the GST rate now would be 40 per cent as against 28 per cent earlier. This segment includes some of the most popular cars in India, such as the Hyundai Creta and Toyota Fortuner.

Although, it is worth noting that while the GST on these cars will increase, the overall tax burden could be moderate because so far, these cars were subject to an additional compensation cess of 17-22 per cent, taking the total tax to 50 per cent in some cases. With the GST changes including removal of the compensation cess, the hike in base GST rate to 40 per cent will actually imply similar or slightly lower tax incidence for bigger SUVs.

“This decision will not only make vehicles more affordable across all segments, thereby boosting consumer demand, but it will also simplify the classification disputes that have long been a source of ambiguity for the industry. The discontinuance of the cess, in particular, will provide crucial support to a sector that is a vital engine of our nation’s economic growth,” said Saurabh Agarwal, Partner and Automotive Tax Leader, EY India.

Hybrids to get cheaper too

Until now, hybrid cars – which have a combination of an internal combustion engine and an electric motor – were subject to a GST of 28 per cent and compensation cess of 15 per cent, which makes the total applicable tax rate on these vehicles 43 per cent. But, with the rationalisation process, hybrid cars with an engine capacity of less than 1200 cc and a length shorter than 4 metres will attract a GST of 18 per cent, with the ones bigger than this category attracting a tax of 40 per cent.

In effect, this could push manufacturers to build smaller hybrid vehicles to take advantage of the tax benefits, and consumers are likely to purchase them due to the added advantage they offer on fuel savings. Maruti Suzuki, for instance, is learnt to be working on a hybrid version of its popular compact SUV Fronx.

In EVs, no differentiation between premium and common

The GST Council has decided to retain the concessional 5 per cent GST rate on electric vehicles (EVs), against earlier speculation that luxury end EVs could see an increase in taxes. This means domestic launches like Tata’s Harrier EV and Mahindra’s XEV 9e would be able to avoid price hikes, while imported models from companies like Tesla, Mercedes-Benz, Audi, BMW, and BYD will also stay within the same concessional bracket.

“The GST Council’s move to retain a low rate for EVs is a welcome step; this brings much-needed clarity and makes our portfolio more accessible to our discerning buyers. Such reforms help stabilise the business environment and help devise strategies that benefit all stakeholders in the best possible manner,” Balbir Singh Dhillon, Head of Audi India said in a statement to The Indian Express.

Due to initial expectation that luxury end EVs could be taxed under a higher bracket following the new reforms, EV sales in August registered a 155 per cent increase over last year, as people moved to buy the vehicles anticipating an increase in prices. Internal combustion engine powered passenger vehicle sales in August declined by over 7 per cent compared to last year, as people waited for the new rates to kick in, given that there was anticipation that such cars could be taxed lower.
summary:
Complete Summary
The article outlines the impact of the GST Council's latest "GST 2.0" reforms on India's automotive sector, with significant changes in tax incidence designed to boost the industry and overall consumption. The new GST structure introduces two primary slabs—5% and 18%—and reserves a 40% “demerit” rate for super luxury, sin, and demerit goods. The reforms aim to lower tax burdens on consumers, simplify classifications, unlock working capital, and streamline processes such as refunds and registration.

Key impacts on vehicles:

Small cars and mini SUVs (petrol engines ≤1200 cc, diesel ≤1500 cc, and length ≤4m) move from 28% to the 18% GST slab, reducing taxes on popular models such as Maruti Suzuki Wagon R, Fronx, Tata Punch, and Skoda Kylaq.

Motorcycles with engine capacity <350 cc and all automotive parts now fall under the 18% rate.

Large cars and SUVs (petrol >1200 cc, diesel >1500 cc, and length >4m) shift to the 40% rate from the prior 28%. However, these vehicles previously attracted a 17–22% compensation cess, bringing the effective total tax to ~50%. With the elimination of this cess, the overall tax for bigger SUVs may remain similar or even decrease slightly, depending on the model (notably for Hyundai Creta, Toyota Fortuner).

Industry experts, such as Saurabh Agarwal (EY India), argue this will not only boost demand and affordability but also resolve long-standing classification ambiguities in the automotive sector.

Hybrid and Electric Vehicles:

Hybrids: Previously subject to a 28% GST plus 15% cess (totaling 43%). Under new rules, small hybrids (<1200 cc, <4m) attract 18% GST, and larger hybrids fall under 40%. This incentivises smaller, fuel-efficient hybrids and offers consumer tax savings.

Electric Vehicles (EVs): The Council retains a concessional 5% GST for all EVs, regardless of segment, averting earlier speculation that luxury EVs would lose this concession. This supports both affordable and premium EV models (e.g., Tata Harrier EV, Mahindra XEV 9e, Tesla, Mercedes-Benz, Audi, BMW, BYD) without a price increase.

Audi India’s head, Balbir Singh Dhillon, praised the reforms as providing business predictability and wider access to buyers.

Market Impact:

Anticipation of higher EV taxes had already caused a 155% surge in EV sales in August compared to the prior year; meanwhile, sales of internal combustion engine (ICE) cars dropped by over 7% as buyers delayed purchases, expecting more favorable GST rates for these vehicles.

Heavy rain and floods have battered States in northern India in the past few days, causing severe damage to life and property. 

Amidst Punjab witnessing heavy rainfall, around 37 lives have been lost due to severe flood, announced the State government on Thursday (September 4, 2025).

Meanwhile, in the national capital, the water level in the Yamuna river at Old Railway Bridge stood at 207.48 metres on Thursday morning, even as floodwater from the raging river continued to inundate nearby areas.
The Central government has deputed an inter-ministerial team to pay detailed on-ground visits to the flood-affected districts in the Jammu region in the next four days and assess the actual scale of losses and damage caused by recent rains.

Follow the live updates here:

    September 04, 2025 12:59
    ‘We will be left with no forests’, Supreme Court on floods, illegally felled Himalayan trees flowing in swollen rivers

    The Supreme Court pointed to repeated flash floods and huge numbers of logs of illegally felled Himalayan trees flowing in swollen rivers, saying “if this goes on, we will be left with no forests”.

    The court on Thursday voiced a deep anguish about floods in the States of Uttarakhand, Himachal Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir and Punjab, and highlighted that media visuals of huge numbers of logs flowing in flood waters indicate that illegal felling of the ecologically sensitive Himalayan forests was going on amidst the chaos and deaths caused by repeated natural disasters.

    Read more here
    September 04, 2025 12:29
    37 lives lost due to severe floods, says Punjab government

    Around 37 lives have been lost due to severe flood, announces the State government.

    According to government of Punjab, around 1,655 villages have been affected, with Gurdaspur the most affected area of the lot, as 324 villages are impacted by flooding, followed by Ferozepur (111), Amritsar (190), Hoshiarpur (121), Kapurthala (123) and Sangrur (107), whose villages were significantly impacted by floods.

    Further, the Punjab government said that around 1,75,216 hectares of total land have been affected. Gurdaspur was most affected, as 40,169 hectares of crop land were impacted due to heavy rain. Additionally, crop land in Mansa (24967), Sangrur (6560), Fazilika (17786) and Kapurthala (3000) were also affected.

    -ANI
    September 04, 2025 12:18
    Commuters navigate through waterlogging near Nigam Bodh Ghat
    September 04, 2025 12:04
    Kapurthala rail parts manufacturer builds boats for relief, rescue efforts

    At a time when boats are the only means to access several flood-hit areas in Punjab, a Kapurthala-based firm is making and delivering boats to supplement relief efforts in the State, which is battling the worst deluge since 1988.

    Pritpal Singh Hanspal, whose firm Hanspal Traders is engaged in manufacturing railway coach parts for the Rail Coach Factory, says he was just doing “sewa” (voluntary service) by giving boats to those in need of them for conducting relief and rescue operations in flood-ravaged districts.

    “We have so far given 50 boats in just one week,” Mr. Hanspal adds.

    -PTI
    September 04, 2025 11:40
    Educational institutions in Kashmir shut for second day due to flood-like situation

    Educational institutions in Kashmir remained closed for the second day in view of the flood-like situation following heavy rainfall in the valley over the past two days.

    “In view of adverse weather conditions and as a precautionary measure, Divisional Commissioner Kashmir, Anshul Garg, ordered the closure of all educational institutions, including schools, colleges, universities and coaching centres across Kashmir on Thursday, 4th of September, 2025,” an official spokesperson said.

    -PTI
    September 04, 2025 11:34
    NDRF conducts search operation near Yamuna Bazar area
    September 04, 2025 11:22
    Jammu-Srinagar NH, other vital roads closed for traffic

    Kashmir Valley was cut off from the rest of the country as all surface links, including the Jammu-Srinagar National Highway, were closed for traffic on Thursday due to multiple landslides and the washing away of road patches due to rains.

    The closure of highways and other inter-regional roads since August 26 has resulted in over 3,500 vehicles getting stuck at various places from Kathua to Kashmir. 

    With the closure of the Jammu-Srinagar highway, Mughal Road, Sinthan-Anantnag Road, Jammu-Poonch highway and Batote-Doda-Kishtwar highway, all surface connectivity to Kashmir Valley has been cut off, officials said. - PTI
    September 04, 2025 11:21
    Punjab releases ₹71 crore for 12 flood-hit districts

    The state government has released a fund of ₹71 crore to deal with the current floods. A sum of ₹35.50 crore was released earlier to all districts.

    Additional Chief Secretary-cum-Financial Commissioner, Revenue, Anurag Verma, said the latest funding is meant for, among others, Amritsar, Bathinda, Barnala, Faridkot, Ferozepur, Fazilka, Fatehgarh Sahib and Gurdaspur. - PTI
    September 04, 2025 11:19
    Jhelum river crosses danger mark

    Authorities in Kashmir issued an advisory to people living in houseboats on the Dal Lake to take precautionary measures in case water from the River Jhelum needs to be diverted to the water body.

    The water level in River Jhelum has crossed the danger mark of 21 feet.

    “To regulate this surge, the gate at Ram Munshi Bagh may be opened at any time, as part of emergency water level management measures. The potential opening of this gate is expected to cause a further rise in the water level of Dal Lake, which currently stands at 10.5 feet. This rise may pose a significant risk of inconvenience to Dal dwellers and houseboat owners,” a spokesman said. - PTI
    September 04, 2025 11:02
    Jammu-Katra shuttle service suspended for second day

    The Jammu-Katra shuttle train service, which was started to facilitate the movement of locals and stranded passengers, was suspended for the second day in the wake of floods and landslides.

    Chief Public Relations Officer Himanshu Shekhar Upadhyay said, railways has been running special trains to ferry stranded passengers from Jammu to their destinations over the past four days.

    A total of 5,784 stranded passengers have been ferried in seven trains from Jammu for their onward journey. - PTI
    September 04, 2025 10:52
    NDRF reaches Yamuna Bazaar for rescue operation

    Commandant of the 16th Battalion, NDRF, Abujam Bijoy Kumar Singh says, “The water levels have stabilised. According to forecasts, by 8 p.m., water levels are expected to recede, and the danger that has persisted since yesterday will reduce.” - PTI

    September 04, 2025 10:43

    Educational institutions in Kashmir remained closed for the second day on Thursday in view of the flood-like situation following heavy rainfall in the valley over the past two days.

    “In view of adverse weather conditions and as a precautionary measure, Divisional Commissioner Kashmir, Anshul Garg ordered the closure of all educational institutions, including schools, colleges, universities and coaching centres across Kashmir on Thursday, 4th of September, 2025,” an official spokesperson said. - PTI

    J-K: Rainfall continues to lash Bhaderwah for third consecutive day

    Rainfall continues to lash the Bhaderwah region of the Doda district of Jammu and Kashmir for the third consecutive day. 

    The Regional Meteorological Centre has issued a red alert of “heavy rain” for Doda district for the day, along with Rajouri, Reasi, Jammu, Udhampur, Ramban and Kishtwar districts. 

    The orange alert of heavy rain has been issued for Samba, Kathua, Budgam, Shopian, Kulgam, Bandipora, Baramulla, Pulwama and Ganderbal. The yellow alerts have been issued for Anantnag, Srinagar and Kupwara districts for the day. 

    In Srinagar, the water level in the Jhelum River has been continuously rising following heavy rainfall. 

    Continuous heavy rainfall has been witnessed in several parts of Jammu and Kashmir, with rivers swelling and flash flood-like conditions reported across multiple districts.

    -ANI
    September 04, 2025 08:42
    Wednesday recap: Rain fury claims dozens of lives across northern States

    Heavy rain and floods continued to batter States in northern India on Wednesday (September 3, 2025), causing severe damage to life and property. 

    In Himachal Pradesh, 11 people died in the past 24 hours, during which rain triggered landslides. In Punjab, the swollen Sutlej, Beas, and Ravi rivers caused widespread devastation, with the State government pegging the death toll in recent rain-related incidents to 37.

    In Jammu and Kashmir (J&K), two people were killed and hundreds were rescued following a heavy downpour. The Jhelum and Chenab rivers were flowing above the danger mark.

    IMD issues red alert warnings for multiple Indian states due to heavy rainfall, posing risks of floods and landslides.

    A fresh spell of heavy rains compounded the flood situation in Punjab with the death toll rising to 37 on Wednesday, while crops on 1.75 lakh hectares of land in 23 districts got damaged by the worst deluge in the state since 1988.

    Rescue and relief operations are underway on a war footing as help poured in from several quarters for over 3.55 lakh people in 1,655 villages, desperately looking for succour.

    -PTI
    September 04, 2025 08:37

    Nearly 100 border outposts of the Border Security Force (BSF) and around 110 kilometres of fencing along the Pakistan border in Jammu and Punjab have been affected due to the unprecedented rain and floods in the region, a senior government official said on Wednesday (September 3, 2025).

    The official said the BSF personnel are deployed on “high ground” and are taking the help of drones and surveillance tools to keep a check on activities along the International Boundary (IB).

    Punjab government extends school closures due to floods, impacting over 3.50 lakh people, until September 7, 2025.

    Jammu floods: GoI deputes inter-ministerial team to assess actual scale of damage

    The Central government has deputed an inter-ministerial team to pay detailed on-ground visits to the flood-affected districts in the Jammu region in the next four days and assess the actual scale of losses and damage caused by recent rains.

    This was revealed at a high-level meeting chaired by Jammu Divisional Commissioner Ramesh Kumar, and the inter-ministerial team head and National Disaster Management Authority of India Joint Secretary Col Kirti Pratap Singh here on Wednesday night.

    The meeting was held to discuss the scale of damages caused by the recent cloudbursts, flash floods and landslides in Jammu region.

    “Over the next four days, the inter-ministerial team will conduct detailed on-ground visits to the affected areas to assess the actual scale of losses and damages in the districts of Jammu division. It shall then submit a detailed report to the Government of India,” a government spokesperson said.

    The Central team comprises officials from the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways, Ministry of Power, Ministry of Rural Development, Department of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare, Ministry of Jal Shakti, and Ministry of Finance.

    -PTI
    September 04, 2025 08:35
    Nigambodh ghats shut in Delhi as Yamuna river breaches 207-metre mark

    Waters from a raging Yamuna submerged homes, destroyed shop goods and disrupted traffic in several areas, throwing life out of gear for thousands of people in the national capital, as the river breached the 207-metre mark on Wednesday (September 3, 2025) for the fifth time since 1963. 

    The water from the flooded river also entered the Nigambodh Ghat, Delhi’s oldest and busiest cremation ground, forcing it to halt operations.

    Read more here:
    Nigambodh ghats shut in Delhi as Yamuna river breaches 207-metre mark

    Delhi's Nigambodh Ghat and Geeta Colony crematorium halt operations due to flooding, displacing thousands in the city.
summary:
Northern India is grappling with widespread devastation due to heavy rains and severe flooding across multiple states, resulting in significant loss of life and property damage. In Punjab alone, state officials have confirmed that around 37 people have died, with about 1,655 villages affected—Gurdaspur being the hardest-hit district. Approximately 1.75 lakh hectares of agricultural land have been submerged or damaged.

The national capital, Delhi, is also under threat, as the Yamuna river’s water level at the Old Railway Bridge reached 207.48 metres on Thursday morning, inundating low-lying areas and key civic infrastructure. Authorities have deployed National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) teams for rescue and relief, and several areas—including the busy Nigambodh Ghat cremation ground—have been flooded and forced to cease regular operations.

Jammu and Kashmir faces persistent flood-like conditions, prompting the closure of all educational institutions across the Kashmir Valley for consecutive days. The water level of the Jhelum river has crossed the danger mark, and advisories have been issued for houseboat owners on Dal Lake. Multiple vital roads and highways, such as the Jammu-Srinagar National Highway and Mughal Road, remain closed due to landslides and flooding, leaving over 3,500 vehicles stranded.

The Central government has dispatched an inter-ministerial team to assess damages in Jammu, while Punjab has released ₹71 crore for flood-hit districts. Relief efforts include local companies building boats for rescue operations. The Supreme Court has expressed deep concern about the repeated devastation, attributing much of the destruction to illegal felling of Himalayan forests—which has led to massive logs flowing in swollen rivers—and warning, “if this goes on, we will be left with no forests.”

The India Meteorological Department has issued red and orange alert warnings for several regions, highlighting ongoing risks due to continued rainfall and possible landslides. The scale of impact is likened to, or worse than, previous extreme flood years such as 1988.

A special investigation team (SIT) of Karnataka CID has submitted a closure report to the high court, stating that the gang-rape complaint against BJP MLA N Munirathna Naidu and his four associates was found to be false. The SIT presented its closure report on Wednesday to the court, which adjourned further hearing on Munirathna’s petition to September 17 and extended its interim order restraining police from taking coercive action against him.

The complaint had originally been filed in May by a 40-year-old social worker, who alleged that Munirathna masterminded her gang-rape at his office on June 11, 2023. She claimed that two of Munirathna’s aides took her to his office under the pretext of clearing a criminal case, and that she was raped there in Munirathna’s presence, with the MLA allegedly urinating on her. However, a senior IPS officer told media, “There wasn’t a single piece of evidence to establish the allegations.” The SIT filed a ‘B report’, effectively declaring the complaint false.

Previously, Munirathna and his associates were chargesheeted by the SIT in a separate honey-trapping and attempted AIDS infection case, and Munirathna was chargesheeted in November last year for allegedly verbally abusing an ex-corporator.

The report includes a reader poll on the MLA’s interim order staying police action and links to other Bengaluru news.
summary:
A special investigation team (SIT) from the Karnataka Criminal Investigation Department (CID) has submitted a closure report to the high court, concluding that gang-rape charges brought against BJP MLA N Munirathna Naidu and four of his associates were found to be false. This closure report was presented on Wednesday, September 4, 2025, and the court has adjourned further hearing on Munirathna’s petition to September 17, extending its interim order that restrains police from taking coercive action against him.

The allegations had originated from a complaint filed in May by a 40-year-old social worker, who accused Munirathna of masterminding a gang rape at his office on June 11, 2023. According to the complaint, two of Munirathna’s associates lured the complainant under the pretense of clearing a criminal case in exchange for help, after which she was allegedly raped in his presence. The woman further claimed that Munirathna urinated on her. However, a senior IPS officer told the media that the SIT found "not a single piece of evidence to establish the allegations," resulting in the issuance of a 'B report,' effectively designating the complaint as false.

Prior to this, Munirathna and others had been chargesheeted by the SIT in a separate honey-trapping and attempted AIDS infection case. Munirathna was also chargesheeted in November of the previous year for allegedly verbally abusing an ex-corporator.

The article includes a brief poll for readers regarding their views on the restraining interim order for the MLA, and situates this update alongside links to related civic, legal, and political news in Bengaluru.

DK Shivakumar proposes border towers to demarcate 5 new corporation in Bengaluru

TNN / Sep 04, 2025, 05:27 IST

Bengaluru: With Greater Bengaluru Authority (GBA) now having formally replaced Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP), citizens are vexed by a question: How exactly will the limits of the five newly created city corporations be marked on the ground?
Deputy chief minister DK Shivakumar has suggested installation of border towers to clearly demarcate the jurisdiction of each corporation.
Speaking at the inauguration of the GBA headquarters here on Tuesday, Shivakumar said the state will also lay the foundation stones for new municipal offices on November 1, coinciding with Kannada Rajyotsava.

"Boundary towers will be erected along the limits of all five corporations to make the divisions visible," he said. The move, officials say, will help citizens know which civic body to approach for services or grievances.

The initiative echoes Kempegowda's vision, who, more than four centuries ago, had marked Bengaluru's territorial limits by erecting four iconic watch towers with the Dharmarayaswamy temple as the central edifice. These include the Lalbagh (South East), Gavipura (South West), Mehkri Circle (North West), and Ulsoor (North East) towers, which continue to symbolise the city's heritage.

In 2014, BBMP had announced plans to construct Kempegowda towers on 10 major arterial roads connecting Bengaluru, with each tower estimated to cost around Rs 10 crore.
The project, though, never moved beyond announcements.
By reviving the concept in a new form, Shivakumar has drawn a symbolic link between the city's founder and Bengaluru's expansion under GBA.

He also announced major administrative restructuring under the GBA, including the addition of 300 engineers to strengthen civic works. "We are appointing one engineer for every ward. Around 500 engineers at lower levels will ensure transparency and proper groundwork," Shivakumar said.

A proposal to increase the number of wards from 198 to 500 was submitted, with Rs 300 crore allocated for administrative expenses, salaries, and pensions.
"Elections must first be held in the newly formed municipalities. Only later will mergers be considered," the deputy CM clarified.

Name suggestions
On the demand to include Kannada words in the GBA title, deputy CM D K Shivakumar said: "I would like to ask for advice on what name to give. The same situation had arisen in other places, including Mumbai. There is no question of ignoring the mother tongue, but if we find a good [alternative] word, let's change it."

‘Patience' over potholes is GBA chief's mantra
As motorists continue to struggle on crater-filled roads all across the city, GBA chief commissioner Maheshwar Rao urged Bengalureans to "be patient," citing multiple urban challenges delaying road repair work.

The newly appointed GBA chief, under whose jurisdiction the five new corporations operate, made the statement in response to criticism over poor execution of pothole-filling works.
Rao ruled out any issue with the quality of bitumen used for pothole repairs, saying other factors included incessant rain and overlapping activities by various agencies.

He also noted that it takes 12-24 hours for repair work to settle in once completed, but motorists begin using the roads right away, sometimes nullifying fresh repairs.
summary:
Complete Summary
The article reports on Deputy Chief Minister DK Shivakumar’s proposal to erect border towers to clearly demarcate the limits of the five newly created city corporations in Bengaluru, replacing the former Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP) with the new Greater Bengaluru Authority (GBA). Shivakumar announced the initiative at the inauguration of the GBA headquarters, noting that boundary towers would make the divisions easily visible and help residents identify the correct civic body for services and complaints.

This move draws on historical symbolism: Kempegowda, Bengaluru’s founder, had similarly demarcated the city’s boundaries centuries ago with iconic watch towers. Shivakumar also referred to an earlier, unrealized 2014 BBMP proposal to build Kempegowda towers on arterial roads.

Further administrative reforms under the GBA were announced, including adding 300 engineers for ward-level civic work supervision and increasing the number of municipal wards from 198 to 500, with a Rs 300 crore budget allocated for administration, salaries, and pensions. Shivakumar clarified that municipal elections must be completed before considering the merger of any corporations.

The article also touches on the discussion about including Kannada language in the new GBA’s name, with Shivakumar open to suggestions but asserting the importance of the mother tongue.

The article concludes with comments from the new GBA chief commissioner Maheshwar Rao, who urged the public to be patient about pothole repairs, attributing delays to persistent rain and the complexity of coordinating multiple urban agencies. Rao insisted that the quality of materials used was not the issue, and that repaired roads need time to settle before vehicles use them.

A 45-year-old painter, Manigandan, was killed and his assistant, Ningesh (35), was injured after their bike was struck by a mini-goods vehicle on Doddabasti Main Road, west Bengaluru, on Wednesday morning.

Both residents of Vijayanagar, Manigandan and Ningesh were on their way to work when the incident happened. According to police, Manigandan tried to overtake a BMTC bus from the left as the bus stopped at a bus stop. A mini-goods vehicle hit their two-wheeler from behind, causing both men to fall. The bike got sandwiched between the goods vehicle and the bus. Manigandan sustained severe head injuries and was declared dead en route to the hospital. Ningesh suffered leg injuries and is undergoing treatment.

The mini-goods vehicle’s driver, Gangadhar, has been booked by police. The BMTC clarified that the bus was not at fault, stating that the accident occurred when Manigandan tried to overtake from the left.

In other Bengaluru traffic incidents:

A 52-year-old man, Riyaz Pasha (aka Naseer), fell while trying to board a moving BMTC bus near KR Market and was run over, resulting in his death.

In Jaraganahalli, Gangadhar, a 65-year-old businessman, died after his scooter was knocked down by a KSRTC bus.

In Chikkajala, a 27-year-old mason, Ramakrishna Burman, was killed after being knocked down by a vehicle.

On Kanakapura Main Road, a truck struck and killed 35-year-old cook Jaya Pratap, who was riding a motorbike.

The Trump administration asked the the Supreme Court to rule quickly on the tariff issue and order that the president has the power to impose sweeping import taxes under federal law.

The government called on the court to reverse an appeals court ruling that said most of President Donald Trump’s tariffs are an “illegal” use of an emergency powers law.
Also Read | GST Council meeting: Can GST reforms offset the impact of Trump’s tariffs?

The US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit left the tariffs in place for now, but the administration nevertheless called on the high court to intervene quickly in a petition filed electronically late Wednesday and provided to The Associated Press.

It was expected to be formally docketed on Thursday.

Solicitor General D. John Sauer asked the justices to take up the case and hear arguments in early November.

“That decision casts a pall of uncertainty upon ongoing foreign negotiations that the President has been pursuing through tariffs over the past five months, jeopardizing both already negotiated framework deals and ongoing negotiations,” he wrote. “The stakes in this case could not be higher.”

But the stakes are also high for small businesses battered by tariffs and uncertainty, said Jeffrey Schwab, senior counsel and director of litigation at the Liberty Justice Center.

“These unlawful tariffs are inflicting serious harm on small businesses and jeopardizing their survival. We hope for a prompt resolution of this case for our clients,” he said.

The businesses have twice prevailed, once at a federal court focused on trade and again with the appeals court's 7-4 ruling.

The tariffs and their erratic rollout have shaken global markets, alienated U.S. trading partners and allies and raised fears of higher prices and slower economic growth.

But Trump has also used the levies to pressure the European Union, Japan and other countries into accepting new trade deals. Revenue from tariffs totaled $159 billion by late August, more than double what it was at the same point the year before.

Most judges on the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit found the 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act, or IEEPA, did not let Trump usurp congressional power to set tariffs. The dissenters, though, said the law does allow the president to regulate importation during emergencies without explicit limitations.

The ruling involves two sets of import taxes, both of which Trump justified by declaring a national emergency: the tariffs first announced in April and the ones from February on imports from Canada, China and Mexico.

The Constitution gives Congress the power to impose taxes, including tariffs. But over the decades, lawmakers have ceded authority to the president, and Trump has made the most of the power vacuum.

Some Trump tariffs, including levies on foreign steel, aluminum and autos, weren’t covered by the appeals court ruling. It also does not include tariffs Trump imposed on China in his first term that were kept by Democratic President Joe Biden.

Trump can impose tariffs under other laws, but those have more limitations on the speed and severity with which he could act.

The government has argued that if the tariffs are struck down, it might have to refund some of the import taxes that it’s collected, delivering a financial blow to the US Treasury.

While Beijing and Moscow have sought to project unity in the face of Western influence, Hegseth said, "Demonstrations and parades are good, but the United States hopes they will not manifest themselves in the form of a real military conflict."
S President Donald Trump has directed the Department of Defence to strengthen preparations aimed at deterring Russia and China, according to Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth.

He said that Washington does not seek confrontation with either country, but wants to maintain a strong deterrence posture.
Speaking to Fox News, Hegseth connected Beijing’s recent military parade -- attended by the leaders of China, Russia and North Korea -- to what he called the shortcomings of the previous US administration.

"Unfortunately, the weakness of the previous administration has driven Russia and China closer together. That's a terrible development of a lack of American leadership," Hegseth said. "But that’s why President Trump has charged us at the Defence Department to be prepared, to rebuild our military in historic ways, to restore the warrior ethos and re-establish deterrence. Not because we seek conflict, we do not."

Hegseth stressed that US preparations are defensive in nature, adding, "We've made that clear to China, Russia and other countries. It's because being prepared prevents conflict."
US STRATEGY CENTRED ON MILITARY ADVANTAGE

"So we know what they believe and who they are. We also know how strong we are and what military advantages we have. They also know this," Hegseth said.

"Our task is to maintain these military advantages in space, in the air, at sea, underwater and with long-range weapons. All of our capabilities, 'Golden Dome', that China knows it cannot replicate, and we will do so within this administration," he added.

While Beijing and Moscow have sought to project unity in the face of Western influence, Hegseth said, "Demonstrations and parades are good, but the United States hopes they will not manifest themselves in the form of a real military conflict."

Despite the strong rhetoric on deterrence, Hegseth pointed out that President Trump values diplomatic channels with Beijing.

"Trump has a great relationship with President Xi, and he will use that to hopefully find ways to cooperate," Hegseth said.
BEIJING PARADE MARKS WWII ANNIVERSARY

The military parade that triggered Hegseth’s comments took place in Beijing on September 3 to commemorate the 80th anniversary of China’s victory over Japan in World War II.
The parade itself was a dazzling show of strength -- Xi, dressed in a Mao-style tunic, rode past ranks of troops and cutting-edge weaponry, from hypersonic missiles to underwater drones. Fighter jets roared overhead, helicopters carried vast banners, and 80,000 “peace” birds were released into the skies.

Chinese President Xi Jinping was joined by Russian President Vladimir Putin and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The three leaders were seated next to one another, signalling a display of solidarity amid mounting tensions with the West.
summary:
Complete Summary
The article discusses growing global military tensions, focusing on responses from the United States after a high-profile military parade in Beijing that featured Chinese, Russian, and North Korean leaders. Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth states that President Donald Trump has directed the U.S. Department of Defence to strengthen preparations for deterring Russia and China—emphasizing that the U.S. seeks no confrontation, but aims to maintain a formidable deterrence posture.

Speaking on Fox News, Hegseth attributes the increasing closeness between Russia and China to the perceived weaknesses of the prior U.S. administration, labeling it a failure of American leadership. He explains that the Trump administration is “rebuilding the military in historic ways” to restore American military ethos and ensure credible deterrence. According to Hegseth, such preparations are defensive and intended to prevent—not provoke—conflict, and this is “made clear” to both adversaries and allies.

Hegseth further elaborates that the essence of U.S. military strategy is maintaining an advantage across all domains: space, air, sea, underwater, and long-range weaponry. He touts U.S. capabilities (including reference to “Golden Dome”—possibly symbolic of a layered defense system) that China “cannot replicate,” asserting that these will be preserved under the Trump administration.

Despite the strong language regarding military readiness, Hegseth points out Trump values diplomatic engagement, describing a “great relationship” with China’s President Xi Jinping and expressing hope for cooperation.

The military parade that occasioned Hegseth’s comments took place in Beijing on September 3, commemorating the 80th anniversary of China’s World War II victory over Japan. The display featured President Xi riding past ranks of military personnel, hypersonic missiles, underwater drones, fighter jets, banners, and the release of 80,000 peace birds. Russian President Vladimir Putin and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un were seated beside Xi, visually projecting unity among the three nations amid mounting tensions with Western countries.

Tamil Nadu School Teacher Makes Kids Massage Her Feet, Probe Underway

Last Updated: September 03, 2025, 11:35 IST

A headmaster at a school in Tamil Nadu allegedly made students massage her feet, prompting an enquiry after the video went viral on social media.

In a disturbing incident reported from Tamil Nadu, a school headmaster allegedly asked students to massage her feet while she was lying on a table. The local media channels shared the video of the incident where students can be seen pressing the legs of the headmaster.

As per a report by India Today, the incident took place at Maveripatti Primary School in Tamil Nadu’s Dharmapuri district.

The school headmaster, identified as Kalaivani, was seen lying on the table allegedly asking students to press her legs. The purported video of the entire incident is being shared widely on social media prompting an enquiry against the headmaster.

As per the officials, actions will be taken against the headmaster after the enquiry is over.

A similar incident was reported in Tamil Nadu last year. A video of a government school was widely circulated on social media showing a maths teacher sleeping during work hours and asking students to massage his feet. The teacher, J Jayaprakash from Kamakkapalayam in Thalaivasal, was working at the school for 17 years.

As the video went viral, Jayaprakash was placed under suspension by School Education Minister Anbil Mahesh Poyyamozhi. The action was taken on the basis of an investigation report. School Education Department officials in Salem conducted an investigation.

The matter created quite a buzz and students came forward in support of the suspended teacher. Over 50 students of East Rajapalayam Government High School blocked the road in protest and demanded to reinstate their maths teacher. They blocked a TNSTC bus and staged a protest in front of their school. Students claimed that their studies will be impacted without a teacher in the school.
summary:
The article reports on an incident in Tamil Nadu where a school headmaster, Kalaivani of Maveripatti Primary School in Dharmapuri district, allegedly instructed students to massage her feet while she lay on a table. A video of the event went viral on social media, prompting an official enquiry. Authorities have announced that action will be taken following the completion of the investigation.

The article also references a similar incident from the previous year, in which a maths teacher, J Jayaprakash, was suspended after a video surfaced showing him sleeping during work hours and asking students to massage his feet. After the video went viral, local education authorities investigated and suspended the teacher. Notably, this action led to student protests in support of the suspended teacher, with over 50 students blocking a bus to demand his reinstatement, citing concerns that their studies would be negatively affected without him.

Both incidents have stirred public debate and official scrutiny regarding teacher conduct and student welfare in Tamil Nadu schools.
