Along the steep mountainous routes that trace a winding path through the craggy hills of Jammu, roads caved in under landslides, forcing the only land route from the rest of India to the region to shut temporarily. The Indian government also mobilised a fleet of military transport aircraft to fast-track the delivery of aid and other essential supplies into the region, where air traffic was closed on Tuesday before operations resumed the following day.
India's National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) and police personnel carry a dead body on a stretcher during rescue operations after Thursday's flash floods in Chositi village, Kishtwar district, Indian-controlled Kashmir, Saturday, Aug. 16, 2025. (AP Photo/Channi Anand)
India’s National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) and police personnel carry a dead body on a stretcher during rescue operations after flash floods in Chasoti village, Kishtwar district, Indian-administered-Kashmir, Saturday, August 16, 2025 [Channi Anand/AP Photo]
‘Waters close in on Kashmir’

Bashash Mahmood, 23, a university law student, was abruptly awakened by a midnight call while sleeping at his hotel in Srinagar. On the line was his cousin, calling from Anantnag—58 kilometres away.

Floodwaters on Wednesday knocked down mobile and electricity towers and severed optical fibre cables, crippling the region’s entire telecommunications infrastructure.

So Bashash could only hear a jumble of crackling words as he tried to make sense of what his cousin was saying. He finally managed to catch an urgent SOS message: floodwaters had surged outside his home in Bijbehara, Anantnag, and his family was in danger.

He took his car and raced along empty roads in the middle of the night, past the Indian army garrison at Badambagh, and through the sprawling saffron fields of Pampore.

When he arrived at Sangam, a canyon where two major rivers in Anantnag join, he rolled down his windows, the rain pelting against his face. “I realised that water had risen dangerously close to the embankment.”

Once he reached home, Bashash got to work and carried household items such as a fridge, furniture and utensils to the second storey of their house, emptying the ground floor.

In the morning, videos went viral showing people paddling rafts through the streets, as water had submerged large parts of South Kashmir, especially Anantnag district.

In Srinagar, the region’s biggest city, panic reached a crescendo on Wednesday afternoon – reinforced by public memories of apocalyptic floods that had struck in 2014.

Back then, floodwaters from swollen rivers had breached the banks, burying large parts of the Kashmir valley. As Bashash recalls, when the waters finally receded 11 years ago, the floods had left two feet of sludge residue that locals scooped up with their bare hands before cleaning their homes to make them livable again. “Just the thought of how hard it was for us to defecate terrifies me. We would rather refuse to eat anything to get ourselves constipated because there were no toilets,” he says.

Haunted by those memories, residents across Kashmir were seen assembling sandbags and plugging gaps to prevent breaches through which the swelling river might come. If it was the Tawi in Jammu, it was the Jhelum river – also a lifeline-turned-threat – that poses the danger in Kashmir. The river crisscrosses its way through the entire length of the Kashmir valley before crossing over into Pakistan.
A Kashmiri man rows a makeshift raft carrying a woman and a child through the flood waters in Srinagar September 20, 2014. Both the Indian and Pakistani sides of the disputed Himalayan region have seen extensive flooding this month with Srinagar particularly hard hit. Hundreds of people have been killed and tens of thousands are homeless. REUTERS/Danish Ismail (INDIAN-ADMINISTERED KASHMIR - Tags: DISASTER TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY)
The floods have revived memories of the devastating floods of 2014. Here, a Kashmiri man rows a makeshift raft carrying a woman and a child through the flood waters in Srinagar September 20, 2014 [Danish Ismail/ Reuters]
Echoes of 2014, pain of 2019

On Wednesday, residents rushed to relocate or move their household goods to higher storeys in their homes in a bid to avoid a repeat of 2014. The family of Nazir Wani, a 70-year-old man suffering from a chronic pulmonary disorder that requires him to continuously have oxygen connected, said they were moving to a different neighbourhood, some 14km away, at a higher altitude.

“Where would we go if the waters rise and we get stuck? Where will we get the oxygen supply from? We are not taking any chances,” said Nousheen Wani, his daughter. The family bundled the old man into a large sports car, his eyebags sagging, as he took heavy breaths. They hauled five cylinders and two oxygen concentrators and slid them between the boot space and the rear seats, before driving away.

These floods have hit Kashmir amid crippling economic woes.

Six years ago, the Indian government stripped the region’s historic special status and demoted it from a state to a federally governed region, a move that escalated tensions with archrival Pakistan. To prevent protests, India imposed a major lockdown, suspending telecommunications and jailing thousands of people. The lockdown strangled the region’s economy, with an estimated economic loss worth $1.5bn.

Echoes of those measures continue to be felt across the region even today. According to the latest Indian government statistics, youth unemployment stands at 17.4 percent, much higher than the national average of 10.2 percent.

The floods threaten to compound that crisis. Abdullah, the elected chief minister in the disputed province, drew parallels with the aftermath of the 2014 floods. Back then, too, he was in the same role, but at the time, Indian-administered Kashmir had semiautonomous status, giving Abdullah, in some ways, more power than other Indian state leaders.

In a post on X, he complained about the failure of authorities to learn from the lessons of 2014. “What flood mitigation measures were implemented since Oct (sic) 2014?” he asked, criticising those who ruled between his two tenures, including Modi’s Bharatiya Janata Party, a coalition partner in the provincial government between 2015 and 2018. “These are all questions that the elected government will seek answers to because the last 48 hours have been a shocking eye-opener.”
Chief Minister of Jammu and Kashmir, Omar Abdullah, in white shirt and a cap, speaks to people affected by Thursday's flash floods in Chositi village, Kishtwar district, Indian-controlled Kashmir, Saturday, Aug. 16, 2025. (AP Photo/Channi Anand)
Chief Minister of Jammu and Kashmir, Omar Abdullah, in white shirt and a cap, speaks to people affected by flash floods in Chasoti village, Kishtwar district, Indian-administered Kashmir, Saturday, August 16, 2025 [Channi Anand/ AP Photo]
‘Decimation of local floodplains’

While extreme weather events continue to occur regularly across India, environmental experts in Kashmir say poor natural resource management and a flurry of reckless developmental projects have amplified threats.

“In the last five years, the authorities have felled up to a million trees for what they call their pasture land retrieval programmes,” explained Raja Muzaffar Bhat, a Srinagar-based activist.

In 2020, authorities in Kashmir began evicting forest-dwelling tribal communities from their homes by cutting down their orchards. Authorities accused the communities of having “encroached” on forest land. However, the “tribals” insist they have been cultivating the land for generations.

Major construction projects, including tunnels bored through mountains, also added to the dangers of ecological collapse, Bhat suggested.

He cited the example of a 61km road project that aims to skirt past traffic-congested Srinagar city and ease access between other districts of Kashmir. The road is being built on floodplains that historically have absorbed surging waters, saving Srinagar from flooding. Instead, Bhat said, it could have been built on elevated pillars.

Tonnes of soil were extracted from precious elevated tablelands called karewas for laying the foundations on which these roads have been built, and they will pass through the floodplains of Kandizal (between the districts of Srinagar and Pulwama), Muzaffar said. The floodplains had an important role as they absorbed the water surge and prevented Srinagar city from being flooded.

Kashmir’s “topographical balance that had existed naturally for hundreds of years” is being disturbed, Muzaffar said. And this week’s floods could soon become the norm.
summary:
Torrential rains in Indian-administered Kashmir have caused devastating landslides and flash floods, killing at least 40 people—many of them Vaishno Devi pilgrims—and leaving scores more injured and missing. Families like that of Ruksana, a widow who built her home by domestic work, have lost everything except their lives, as homes have been swept away or rendered uninhabitable.

Jammu recorded its highest-ever 24-hour rainfall, breaking records set in 1988, and causing widespread damage: bridges across the Tawi river were destroyed, roads collapsed, and essential infrastructure, including telecom and power lines, went down. Relief camps have been set up, over 5,000 people have been evacuated, and political leaders including Chief Minister Omar Abdullah and PM Modi have visited the region and promised support.

Many pilgrims from across northern and central India are among the dead and missing, with families desperately seeking information on their loved ones as communication networks remain crippled. The floods have revived painful memories of the catastrophic 2014 Kashmir floods, prompting widespread panic and urgent measures as residents scramble to protect households and vulnerable family members.

The crisis was made worse by years of economic distress following the abrogation of Kashmir’s autonomous status in 2019, continued unemployment, and a battered local economy. Chief Minister Abdullah has criticized officials for a lack of lasting flood mitigation since 2014 and raised concerns about state and federal government actions, such as the massive felling of trees under land retrieval and development projects—including highway and tunnel construction on vital floodplains. Environmentalists argue these interventions have dangerously destabilized the region's ecological balance, exacerbating the impact of extreme weather events.

news_article:
Entire families are being “wiped out” as Israel intensifies the bombardment of residential areas in Gaza City and makeshift encampments across the Strip, with at least 28 Palestinians killed in attacks since dawn on Thursday.
    Hamas says it is ready for the formation of an independent national administration to run Gaza and for a comprehensive truce deal, which will see all Israeli captives released.

29 UpdatesAuto-updates

2m ago (09:30 GMT)
Two more killed in new Israeli attack on Gaza City

The latest Israeli attack, which hit a house in eastern Gaza City’s Shujayea neighbourhood, has killed at least two people, according to an ambulance source quoted by our colleagues on the ground.

Earlier, our colleagues reported that at least 16 people have been killed by Israeli attacks in Gaza City alone today.
17m ago (09:15 GMT)
Nelson Mandela’s grandson says Palestinians suffering ‘worse form of apartheid’ than Black South Africans did

Nelson Mandela’s grandson, Mandla Mandela, has said the hardship facing Palestinians under Israeli occupation exceeds even that suffered by Black South Africans during apartheid.

Speaking to the Reuters news agency on Wednesday, Mandela, 51, said “many of us that have visited the occupied territories in Palestine have only come back with one conclusion: That the Palestinians are experiencing a far worse form of apartheid than we ever experienced.

“We believe that the global community has to continue supporting the Palestinians, just as they stood side by side with us,” he added.

Mandela gave the comments as he prepared to board a flight to Tunisia to join the Global Sumud Flotilla, aimed to deliver food and humanitarian supplies to Gaza.

He is among 10 South African activists travelling with the flotilla, which includes dozens of boats and hundreds of people from 44 countries, including Swedish activist Greta Thunberg.

South Africa’s African National Congress said the flotilla’s mission “echoes our own struggle for liberation”.
Mandla Mandela, grandson of Nelson Mandela, prepares to board a flight to Tunisia to join the Global Sumud Flotilla aiming to deliver humanitarian supplies to Gaza, at O.R. Tambo International Airport in Johannesburg, South Africa, September 3, 2025. REUTERS/Siyabonga Sishi
Mandla Mandela prepares to board a flight to Tunisia to join the Global Sumud Flotilla, at OR Tambo International Airport in Johannesburg, South Africa, September 3 [Siyabonga Sishi/Reuters]
22m ago (09:10 GMT)
Developing
Projectile lands near vessel in Bab al-Mandeb Strait: Report

The UK Maritime Trade Operations Centre (UKMTO) has sent an alert over “suspicious activity” in the Bab al-Mandeb Strait, some 178 nautical miles (330km) northwest of Yemen’s Hodeidah.

In an alert published on its website, the UKMTO says a vessel travelling in the strait, The Master, reported that an “unknown projectile” landed in the sea “some distance from the vessel”.

The report said the vessel and crew are safe but cautioned other ships to “transit with caution”.

Yemen’s Houthi rebels have previously waged attacks on vessels passing through the strait that they claim are linked to Israel.
32m ago (09:00 GMT)

Gaza
The fuel crisis in Gaza continues due to Israel’s attacks and blockade [Hassan Jedi/Anadolu]

37m ago (08:55 GMT)
Developing
Israeli attack on Gaza City tent camp kills child

Israeli forces have carried out another deadly attack in Gaza City, report our colleagues on the ground.

The attack targeted a tent camp in the west of the city, killing a child and injuring others, they quote local medical sources as saying.

We’ll bring you more information as we have it.
47m ago (08:45 GMT)
Footage shows tents ablaze in Gaza City following deadly Israeli attack

Palestinian activists have shared video clips independently verified by Sanad, Al Jazeera’s fact-checking agency, showing fires breaking out overnight in tents of displaced people in Nassr, a neighbourhood in the west of Gaza City, after they were bombed by Israeli forces.

The attacks killed several Palestinians and wounded many others.
1h ago (08:30 GMT)
Israeli forces make more West Bank arrests

The Palestinian Wafa news agency is reporting another round of Israeli raids and arrests in the occupied West Bank. During their latest incursions, it reports that Israeli forces:

    Arrested five people in towns near Hebron.
    Arrested five people, including a local leader of the Fatah movement, in the Salfit area, and confiscated money and jewellery from another man’s home.
    Set up a military checkpoint and searched vehicles in the town of Beit Dajan, near Nablus.
    Arrested one person in Bethlehem.

1h ago (08:15 GMT)
Analysis
Israel will only respond to ‘sticks’, not ‘carrots’, in ceasefire talks: Analyst

Israel never had “the intention to reach this ceasefire agreement, because they have other plans”, Luciano Zaccara, a Middle East political analyst, has told Al Jazeera.

He said Israel’s far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich’s comments on Wednesday “made it very clear that the intention of Israel is to annex more territories, including [the occupied] West Bank and Gaza“.

“So what is the point in allowing the creation of an entity, either with Hamas or without … that can represent Palestinians when the plan is already set that these territories will belong to Israel sooner or later?” he asked.

“There is no way that Israel would agree to something with Hamas allowing them to survive politically, and allowing the Palestinian entity to be created,” he added.

He said that despite the best efforts of mediators, “[for Israel] there are no more carrots in this conversation, it is only sticks.

“Because the [Israeli] objective is not to negotiate anything, not to give priority to the release of the hostages … but to vacate the whole Gaza Strip in order to implement what they wanted to do, which is [to seize it as] Israeli territory”.

1h ago (08:00 GMT)
‘They erased them all’: Families being decimated in Gaza City

Three-year-old Ibrahim was the sole survivor of an Israeli attack that ripped through a Gaza City apartment and killed his parents and siblings.

There’s grief and relief for his grandmother, Umm Abu al-Abed Abu al-Jubein.

“This column and all the rubble were lying on top of him; I don’t know how, but God saved him,” she said.

“He is the only one. His mother, father and two siblings were lost. We woke up to the boy screaming … We found my daughter in pieces; her husband and daughters were scattered around her.”

Ibrahim is now one of the more than 49,000 children in Gaza who have lost one or both parents, according to health authorities.

UNICEF estimates that at least 17,000 children have been orphaned since Israel’s war on Gaza began.

Entire families are being killed together in their tents and shelters as the Israeli bombardment of Gaza City intensifies.

“My brother was killed, struck inside his room,” displaced Palestinian Sabreen al-Mabhuh said.

“They killed him with his wife and children; they erased them all. No one is left.”

01:47
Three-year-old boy sole survivor of Israeli strike that killed family in Gaza City
1h ago (07:45 GMT)
Gaza City hospitals facing ‘huge pressure’ as casualties mount

By Tareq Abu Azzoum

Reporting from Deir el-Balah, central Gaza

Doctors say they are dealing with a huge influx of casualties that continue to arrive at hospitals.

There is huge pressure on medical teams operating in front-line hospitals in Gaza City, such as al-Ahli Arab Hospital and al-Shifa Hospital. Doctors there report a nonstop surge of air attacks and a large number of people who need life-saving treatment.

In the hospital we’re standing in front of in Deir el-Balah, there are not even enough stretchers to carry people, so volunteers often have to carry people in on their backs or shoulders.

This shows the growing state of emergency and how civilians on the ground are bearing the brunt of Israel’s deadly military campaign.
1h ago (07:45 GMT)
Palestinians continue to flee northern Gaza; south faces more overcrowding, inflation

Palestinians who have fled Gaza City over the past few months have found dire conditions elsewhere in Gaza.

Their arrival has further overcrowded tent camps and pushed prices of basic goods much higher.

“The beach is crowded. Everywhere is crowded. There’s no hygiene. It’s a struggle to get water and food,” Iman el-Naya, from Khan Younis, who fled Gaza City three months ago, told the AP.

“I go and stand in line for water. Getting bread is a struggle. Everything is even more expensive after the people from the north came here,” she said.

Shorouk Abu Eid, a pregnant woman from Gaza City, who was displaced to Khan Younis four months ago, said the arrival of more people from the north is creating an even more tragic situation.

“There is no privacy, no peace of mind,” she told AP.

“Places I used to walk to in five or 10 minutes are taking me around an hour now because of the congestion. There’s barely 10cm [4 inches] between tents,” Abu Eid added.

1h ago (07:35 GMT)
Family ‘wiped out’ in Nuseirat attack amid ‘very bloody night’ in Gaza

By Tareq Abu Azzoum

Reporting from Deir el-Balah, central Gaza

It was a very bloody night for families in Gaza City. There was a deadly series of air strikes and heavy artillery bombardment in the eastern part of the city.

We understand that a number of makeshift tents were hit, killing at least four Palestinians and wounding 15 others who are now receiving emergency treatment in al-Shifa Hospital.

In central Gaza, there was a surge in air strikes on makeshift tents. In the Nuseirat refugee camp, an entire family of seven, including a young girl, was wiped out overnight in one of the deadliest air strikes recorded in the past 12 hours.

The al-Mawasi area of southern Gaza, where people have recently been told to go, has also been under heavy attack.

A makeshift tent was struck with three missiles, killing and wounding several people.
2h ago (07:30 GMT)
UNRWA unable to bring aid into Gaza for 6 months

UNRWA has renewed its call on Israel to lift restrictions on its Gaza aid operations, saying it has been unable to bring in supplies for six months.

“Families in Gaza have been left without essentials. UNRWA has not been allowed to bring in any aid for six months now,” said the agency in a post on X.

“Shelter items like mattresses, blankets and tents are much needed. UNRWA is ready to deliver – the siege must be lifted,” it added.

An Israeli law banning UNRWA from working on Israeli soil or with Israeli authorities came into effect in January, severely affecting the organisation’s life-saving work in Gaza.

Israel has since largely handed over aid distribution in Gaza to the US-backed GHF, whose distribution sites have repeatedly been marred by deadly shootings of aid seekers.
2h ago (07:18 GMT)
Houthi
Israeli forces kill 28 people across Gaza since dawn, 4 of them aid seekers

Medical sources have told Al Jazeera that at least 28 Palestinians have been killed in Israeli attacks across Gaza since dawn, including 16 in Gaza City, as attacks escalate.

At least four aid seekers were among those killed.
2h ago (07:15 GMT)
Only one in four detainees from Gaza in Israeli jails are fighters: Report

A report in the British newspaper The Guardian, citing classified data, says only one in four detainees from Gaza are identified as fighters by Israel’s military intelligence, and civilians make up the “vast majority of Palestinians held without charge or trial in abusive prisons”.

It said those serving long sentences in Israeli jails include medical workers, teachers, civil servants, media workers, writers, sick and disabled people and children.

The newspaper said an 82-year-old woman with Alzheimer’s was jailed by Israeli authorities for six weeks, while a single mother was separated from her young children, and when she was released after 53 days, she found the children begging on the streets.

Israel’s infamous Sde Teiman military base, which doubles as a prison for Palestinians, “at one point held so many sick, disabled and elderly Palestinians that they had their own hangar, dubbed ‘the geriatric pen’,” a soldier serving there said.

2h ago (07:00 GMT)
Israeli military representative doubts Gaza City offensive will defeat Hamas

An Israeli military representative told a Knesset committee that the seizure of Gaza City would not necessarily break Hamas’s hold on the enclave, according to public broadcaster Kan.

During a closed session of the Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee, the representative was asked why occupying Gaza City would compel Hamas “to budge at all”.

“I did not say it would move Hamas, it is not certain at all,” the representative replied, according to Kan. “The city has symbolic significance.”

As we’ve been reporting, Israeli forces are continuing to ramp up attacks in and around Gaza City as they gear up for a full-on invasion. Overnight and into the early morning, Israeli attacks there killed at least nine Palestinians, including four children, according to local hospital sources.

01:47

2h ago (06:45 GMT)
US ‘very troubled’ by Norway’s divestment from Caterpillar over Israeli abuses

President Trump’s administration has said it’s “very troubled” by the Norway’s wealth fund’s decision to divest from US construction equipment group Caterpillar on ethical grounds related to Israel’s war on Gaza.

“We are very troubled by the Norwegian sovereign wealth fund’s decision, which appears to be based on illegitimate claims against Caterpillar and the Israeli government,” a US State Department spokesperson said, according to the Reuters news agency.

“We are engaging directly with the Norwegian government on this matter,” the official added.

In late August, Norway’s $2 trillion wealth fund, the world’s largest, announced it had divested from five Israeli banking groups, as well as Caterpillar Inc, on ethical grounds.

The five banks were excluded “due to an unacceptable risk that the companies contribute to serious violations of the rights of individuals in situations of war and conflict”, the fund said in a statement.

It also said Caterpillar’s products, such as bulldozers, were being used by Israeli authorities “to commit extensive and systematic violations of international humanitarian law” such as the “widespread unlawful destruction of Palestinian property”.

An Israeli armoured Caterpillar D9 bulldozer manoeuvres near the Israel-Gaza fence on April 10, 2024 [Amir Cohen/Reuters]
3h ago (06:30 GMT)
My house ‘keeps dancing, going right and left like an earthquake’

With Israeli bulldozers razing buildings in Gaza City and Israeli leaders supporting the forced mass displacement of Palestinians, departing the city now could mean leaving for good.

“The Israeli forces, when they mark any area by red colour and they request the people to leave, they really will destroy it,” Mohammed al-Kurdi, who is sheltering in Gaza City along with hundreds of thousands of other Palestinians, told The Associated Press.

“So it’s like you decide whether to live or die. It’s very simple like that.”

Al-Kurdi, a project manager and consultant, said he can hear Israeli forces from the apartment where he’s sheltering as they “erase the area completely”.

“It’s not something partial like before. It’s 100 percent,” he said. “The house, I’m telling my friends, it keeps dancing all day. It keeps dancing, going right and left like an earthquake.”

Amal Seyam, the general director of the Women’s Affairs Centre in Gaza, has been displaced five times since the war began.

“Many people have started packing. Many have already left,” she told the AP.

“Do you know what displacement means? It means moving once again, building your life once again, buying new things, blankets, tents, all over again.”

3h ago (06:15 GMT)
Israeli forces arrest 4 near Nablus: Report

Israeli forces have carried out several overnight raids in the occupied West Bank.

According to the Wafa news agency, Israeli forces stormed the city of Nablus and the nearby al-Ein refugee camp, raiding and causing damage to homes before arresting four people.

They also carried out raids in several towns near Bethlehem and Hizma, near Jerusalem, where they shut off several entrances to the town and “dropped threatening leaflets to citizens”, according to Wafa.

Katz warns Israel will launch ‘plague’ on Houthis after latest missile launch

Israel’s Defense Minister said in a post on X that the “Houthis are firing missiles at Israel again”, after the Yemen-based group’s third launch at the country in 24 hours a short while ago.

In response, Katz said Israel would launch a “plague of darkness, a plague of [the death of] the firstborn – we will complete all 10 plagues” against the group.

Two of the missiles were intercepted and the third landed outside of Israel, according to the Israeli military. No injuries have been reported.
4h ago (05:30 GMT)
Judge says Trump admin used anti-Semitism as ‘smokescreen’ for Harvard cuts

A United States federal judge has ruled that the administration of President Donald Trump violated the law when it cancelled research grants worth more than $2.2bn to Harvard University.

The decision from District Judge Allison Burroughs on Wednesday is a major setback for the Trump administration, which has sought to pressure universities into compliance with policies opposing pro-Palestine protests and diversity initiatives.

In her ruling, Burroughs wrote that “a review of the administrative record makes it difficult to conclude anything other than that Defendants used anti-Semitism as a smokescreen for a targeted, ideologically motivated assault on this country’s premier universities.”

Trump has targeted several schools, including Columbia, for their prominent role in the antiwar protests that emerged after Israel launched its war on Gaza in October 2023.

The Trump administration argued that those protests promoted anti-Semitism and created an unsafe environment for Jewish students. Student activists, however, have rejected those assertions.

You can read more here.

4h ago (05:15 GMT)
Developing
Israel says missile launched from Yemen fell in open area

Earlier, we reported that Israel said it had detected a missile launch from Yemen – the third such attack in 24 hours.

The Israeli military has now confirmed that the missile fell in an open area outside Israeli territory and no sirens were activated in the country.
4h ago (05:00 GMT)
Israeli military carries out overnight attacks in ‘night of hell’ in Gaza City

As we have been reporting, the Israeli military has continued its assault on Gaza City overnight, carrying out several deadly attacks on the urban centre.

Al-Aqsa TV reported “another night of hell” in the city, as hospital sources told Al Jazeera Arabic that at least nine Palestinians, including four children, have been killed so far.

Confirmed attacks include:

    Two Palestinians were killed and another is missing following an Israeli strike on a house in the Sabra neighbourhood, south of Gaza City.
    Two people have been killed and others injured in an Israeli strike on a tent housing displaced people in the Tal al-Hawa neighbourhood, southwest of Gaza City.
    One person was killed and others were injured in an Israeli strike on tents housing displaced Palestinians in the Nassr neighbourhood, west of Gaza City.
    Israeli forces have carried out intense artillery shelling around the as-Saftawi neighbourhood in northern Gaza City.
    Israeli forces have detonated a booby-trapped robot among homes near the Sheikh Radwan neighbourhood, north of Gaza City.
    In southern Gaza, several Palestinians were injured when an Israeli drone bombed a tent housing displaced people west of Khan Younis, according to medical staff at the Nasser Medical Complex.

4h ago (04:45 GMT)
WATCH: What does survival look like inside Gaza City?

Al Jazeera continues to report from the ground on the day-to-day reality for more than a million Palestinians still in Gaza City, as the Israeli military escalates its takeover of the Strip’s main urban centre.

As top scholars declare that Israel is committing genocide and US plans for a “Gaza Riviera” continue to circulate, how are Palestinians facing what comes next?

4h ago (04:35 GMT)
A recap of recent developments

Here’s what you need to know:

    At least 73 Palestinians were killed in Israeli attacks across Gaza on Wednesday, including at least 43 people in Gaza City alone, hospital sources told Al Jazeera.
    Hamas said it has agreed to the formation of an independent national administration to run Gaza, and it is ready for a comprehensive truce deal which would see all Israeli captives released.
    Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office rejected Hamas’s statement saying “the war can end immediately” on the conditions set by Israel’s cabinet, including the release of all Israeli captives and the Palestinian group’s disarmament.
    The United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon said Israeli drones dropped four grenades close to peacekeepers on Tuesday morning, calling it one of “the most serious attacks” on its forces since the cessation of hostilities between Israel and Hezbollah in November.
    Israel’s army said it identified the launch of a missile from Yemen in the early hours of Thursday morning – the third in less than 24 hours – and it was working to intercept the threat.
summary:
The humanitarian crisis in Gaza continues to intensify as Israeli bombardment targets residential areas and makeshift shelters across Gaza City, resulting in at least 28 Palestinian deaths since dawn on Thursday. Entire families are being killed in airstrikes—stories include a three-year-old who survived while his family was wiped out, and a tent full of displaced people killed in recent attacks. Hospitals are overwhelmed, lacking enough stretchers and facing an unceasing stream of casualties.

The UN’s relief agency (UNRWA) reports being unable to deliver aid into Gaza for six months due to a tight Israeli blockade, leaving families without essentials. Blockade-induced shortages have also forced many Palestinians to attempt to generate fuel by burning plastic waste, polluting the environment and putting public health at further risk.

The toll on children is catastrophic: over 49,000 children have lost one or both parents and at least 17,000 are orphaned, according to UNICEF and local health authorities. In Gaza’s south, tent camps are overcrowded, with high prices and severe shortages of water, food, and basic supplies.

Internationally, South African activist Mandla Mandela, grandson of Nelson Mandela, likened the Palestinian experience to “a far worse form of apartheid” than Black South Africans suffered, and joined a flotilla heading to deliver aid to Gaza. Norway’s sovereign fund has divested from US-based Caterpillar Inc and Israeli banks over ethical concerns related to Gaza operations. Meanwhile, US officials are pressuring Norway in response to these moves.

In the West Bank, Israeli forces intensified raids and arrests. Regionally, tensions also rose with projectiles landing in the Bab al-Mandeb Strait and continued Houthi missile launches toward Israel.

Analysts suggest Israel will not pursue a ceasefire with Hamas, aiming instead to clear and annex territory. Israeli officials admitted that seizing Gaza City may not defeat Hamas. Ongoing protests within Israel are calling for an end to the war and safe return of Israeli captives.

Hamas, meanwhile, states its willingness for a comprehensive truce deal and to form an independent Gaza administration in exchange for the release of all Israeli captives. Israel’s government maintains its condition for any end to the war: the release of all hostages and the effective disarmament of Hamas.

The Global Sumud Flotilla is continuing on its way to Gaza, trying to break the Israeli blockade on the Palestinian enclave, where a famine has been declared.
    Vessels departed Barcelona on Sunday before turning back as a result of bad weather, and then departing again on Monday.

36 UpdatesAuto-updates

4m ago (09:30 GMT)
Global Sumud Flotilla shares video of its growing fleet of ships

The Global Sumud Flotilla has shared a video on social media showing at least a dozen ships already sailing with the fleet towards Gaza, with more set to join.
2h ago (07:30 GMT)
German activist denounces her country’s role in Gaza genocide

As part of the Global Sumud Flotilla, German lawyer Melanie Schweizer spoke in Tunisia’s capital on Wednesday night about the complicity of the German government in what she described as the genocide in Gaza.

Schweizer said Germany had pledged to never commit or support genocide after the Holocaust, but that it is again “on the side taking part in genocide”. She added that the Global South is leading the charge to stop Israel’s mass killing of Palestinians in Gaza, even as human rights activists are arrested and face charges for similar protests in Western states.

“An event like this would not be possible in Germany, and that’s because of state repression,” she said.

“We are here to set the record straight … to say that our governments do not represent us and that our governments have failed,” Schweizer added.
4h ago (05:30 GMT)
Photos: Italians march in support of Sumud Flotilla
people hold palestinian flags at a protest in Italy
Thousands of people took part in a demonstration in support of the Global Sumud Flotilla in the Sicilian port town of Catania, Italy, on Wednesday [Salvatore Allegra/Anadolu]
people hold palestinian flags at a protest in Italy
Part of Italy’s delegation of ships joining the flotilla is expected to depart from Catania [Salvatore Allegra/Anadolu]
people hold palestinian flags at a protest in Italy

5h ago (03:43 GMT)
Nelson Mandela’s grandson departs to join flotilla

Nkosi Zwelivelile “Mandla” Mandela, grandson of Nelson Mandela, says his journey to join the Sumud Flotilla is a continuation of his “family legacy” and the fight his “beloved country”, South Africa, “has taken to be the voice of the oppressed”.

“Our struggle as South Africa is intertwined with that of the Palestinian people,” Mandela said as he flew out of South Africa to join the flotilla.

“We sail to break the blockade and end the siege on Gaza,” he said.
9h ago (00:00 GMT)
Palestinians continue to go hungry in Gaza

By Hani Mahmoud

Reporting from Gaza City

It’s misleading now to see some of the headlines talking about products and items being allowed into the Gaza Strip.

A brief walk on the streets shows there is a complete absence of protein sources, an absence of fresh produce. It took us half a day, just a couple of days ago, to find 1kg (2.2lb) of tomatoes, and what we found was very old, not fresh, and very, very expensive.

A pick-up truck filled with Nutella jars – this is not addressing the spread of famine.

On the ground, we’re seeing more people going hungry. People are still rationing supplies. Families and mothers are eating one meal a day to provide for their children.

And inside the hospitals, the number of people suffering from acute malnutrition because of the enforced starvation is on the rise.

For more updates from Gaza, go to our live page here.
11h ago (22:00 GMT)
Activists take part in training in Tunis before joining flotilla

Dozens of activists have attended a training day in the Tunisian capital, Tunis, before their expected departure from the North African country on Sunday.

The comedian and activist Kat Nip posted a video of the event, featuring attendees chanting “Free Gaza.”

Also in attendance was Al Jazeera correspondent Fahmida Miller, who is covering the flotilla.

Nip’s video featured various activists explaining why they had chosen to take part in the Global Sumud Flotilla.

“We all know about the atrocities, the genocide. Enough is enough,” said Riyaz Mulla from South Africa. “No government is going to help. It’s up to our super-family of humanity to take the steps and try to break the siege in Gaza.”
13h ago (20:00 GMT)
Italian politicians to join flotilla

The four Italian parliamentarians who will join the Global Sumud Flotilla are Benedetta Scuderi, a member of the European Parliament for the Green Europe party; Annalisa Corrado, a member of the European Parliament and the Democratic Party; Arturo Scotto, an Italian MP also in the Democratic Party; and Senator Marco Croatti of the Five Star Movement.

That is according to Maria Elena Delia, a spokesperson for the Italian delegation of the Global Movement to Gaza who was quoted by the Italian news channel Sky TG24.

“They have decided to lay down their bodies,” Delia said. “You can imagine how important this is.”

Delia said five boats had already departed from Liguria in northern Italy and more would depart on Sunday.

Elly Schlein, the leader of the Democratic Party, the biggest opposition party in the Italian Parliament, said the flotilla has its “full support”.
15h ago (18:00 GMT)
History of prominent names trying to break the blockade of Gaza

By Al Jazeera Staff

Notable names from politics, literature and the arts have consistently staked their reputations and safety in joining attempts to break the blockade Israel has imposed on Gaza.

Here are some of them:

Greta Thunberg: climate activist – currently on board a vessel in the Global Sumud Flotilla, previously on the Madleen (June)

Alice Walker: Pulitzer-winning author of The Color Purple – Audacity of Hope (2011)

Mairead Corrigan Maguire: 1976 Nobel Peace Prize laureate – Mavi Marmara (2010), Women’s Boat (2016)

Henning Mankell: author of the Wallander series – Mavi Marmara (2010)

Moncef Marzouki: former president of Tunisia – Marianne of Gothenburg (2015)

Liam Cunningham: actor – currently on board a vessel in the Global Sumud Flotilla

Basel Ghattas: Palestinian citizen of Israel, former member of the Israeli Knesset – Marianne of Gothenburg (2015)

Ana Maria Miranda Paz: Spanish member of the European Parliament – Marianne of Gothenburg (2015)

Thiago Avila: Brazilian socio-environmentalist and activist – currently on board a vessel in the Global Sumud Flotilla, previously on the Madleen (June)

Chris Smalls: US labour organiser – Handala (July)

17h ago (16:00 GMT)
Global Sumud Flotilla urges European protection after Israel’s threats against Gaza aid mission

By Al Jazeera Staff

The Global Sumud Flotilla has called on European states to protect it following what organisers described on social media as threats from Israel.

Sailing from Barcelona on its way to Gaza last night, the flotilla encountered a number of unidentified drones that remained hovering over the vessels for some time.

Israel’s far-right National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir has also threatened to treat the flotilla’s volunteers as “terrorists” should they continue their journey to deliver food and medicine to the besieged enclave.

Ben-Gvir was previously convicted in Israel of incitement to racism, destroying property, possessing a “terror” organisation’s propaganda material and supporting a “terror” organisation.
19h ago (14:00 GMT)
Spain calls European response to Gaza a ‘failure’ as Israel kills at least 44 Palestinians

Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said earlier on Wednesday that the European response to Israel’s war on Gaza was a “failure”.

“It is a failure,” Sanchez said. “Absolutely. It is also the reality that, within the EU, there are countries that are divided when it comes to how to influence Israel.

“In my opinion, it’s not acceptable and we can’t last longer if we want to increase our credibility when it comes to other crises, such as the one we face in Ukraine.”

It’s been yet another deadly day in Gaza where at least 44 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli forces, including aid seekers, since dawn on Wednesday.

For more updates on Israel’s war in Gaza you can follow our live page here.

 
20h ago (13:30 GMT)
Israeli navy carried out maritime training two days ago

The Israeli army said Wednesday that its navy division conducted maritime drills two days ago, just hours before the Global Sumud Flotilla started its journey from Barcelona.

According to The Times of Israel, the navy troops practised a “variety of combat scenarios”.

The Global Sumud Flotilla has repeatedly said it poses no threat to Israel and is merely trying to open a humanitarian corridor into Gaza, where some two million Palestinians are starving under an Israeli siege.

The activists are sailing through international waters, which means that Israel does not have legal jurisdiction to intercept their boats.

However, Israel has still intercepted previous vessels trying to reach Gaza as part of its maritime blockade of the Strip. The most recent, the Handala, was intercepted by Israeli forces about 160 nautical miles (184 miles) off Gaza’s coast in June.
20h ago (13:00 GMT)
Analysis
‘I love you so much’: Tunisian children to the children of Gaza

By Al Jazeera Staff
ront: From Wassila Zekri. To our brothers and sisters in Gaza. (Metouia, Tunisia). Back: Back: May God protect you and bring you victory. I love you so much. From Hedi to the children of unbowed Gaza
Right: From Wassila Zekri to our brothers and sisters in Gaza, Metouia, Tunisia. Left: May God protect you and bring you victory. I love you so much. From Hedi to the children of undefeated Gaza [Al Jazeera]

Children from across Tunisia are writing letters to the children of Gaza to be carried by the Tunisian boats that will join the Flotilla when it docks.

In one of the donation centres in the capital Tunis, 15-year-old Hedi and her mother were dropping off their donations.,

“Can I please join you in my free time?” she was overheard asking one of the volunteers at the centre.

“I can do anything. I just need to attend my maths session in the mornings, but I’m free for the rest of the day.”

Dozens of other children have shown up at the centre with their animation-themed money boxes and small, personalised gifts.

In Hedi’s letter, the message was simple: “May God protect you and bring you victory. I love you so much.”
21h ago (12:22 GMT)
Flotilla stops in Menorca for refuelling and safety checks

By Al Jazeera Staff

After being battered by storms, the flotilla has stopped in Menorca in Spain’s Balearic Islands to refuel and for safety checks.
21h ago (12:16 GMT)
Life at sea: Training intensifies for volunteers facing challenges and intercept risks

The volunteers’ focus only appears to have increased since last night’s encounter with the drones, writes Mauricio Morales from on board the flotilla.

On board, daily routines are beginning to take shape.

People wake up, and preparations and training sessions are promised for after breakfast.

Under the hot sun and with calmer seas, fire and ship-abandonment drills are carried out.

For some volunteers, it’s their first time putting on lifejackets and facing the practical challenges of life at sea.

Food rationing meetings follow. “Remember, there is starvation in Gaza,” one volunteer reminds the group, setting not only the tone of the mission but also establishing a kind of moral compass for the 24 people from different nationalities and backgrounds who find themselves working together on board this vessel.

Then comes the crucial training: how to respond to a possible interception in international waters by the Israeli army and the boarding of the ship.

The volunteers recall their sessions on non-violence back in Barcelona – never engaging with Israeli soldiers, never touching them in any way, and always keeping their hands visible.

Any break from the non-violent nature of the mission could cost someone their life.

“It’s a strange thing to have to do, but anything is worth it for the solidarity with Palestine,” Isla, a 24-year-old Australian volunteer, whose mother and sister are on board boats within the flotilla, comments.

More training is scheduled for the afternoon and will continue late into the night.

Everyone expects the drones to return.
21h ago (12:00 GMT)
What happened to the US labour activist detained by Israel after the last flotilla?

Chris Smalls was held for five days in an Israeli prison after he participated in the last flotilla that attempted to reach Gaza in July.

He says he was physically abused by Israeli forces during his arrest and detention, and spoke to Al Jazeera’s The Take shortly after his return to the US last month.

You can watch the episode here:

23:09
From Amazon to the Gaza flotilla: The journey of an activist
22h ago (11:30 GMT)
Famine declared in Gaza in August

The UN-backed Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) determined that there was famine in Gaza City and other areas of northern Gaza in August, warning that it would spread to other parts of the Palestinian enclave by September if Israel’s war did not end.

The famine has given added urgency to the Global Sumud Flotilla’s mission to break the siege of Gaza.

The IPC said that the famine in Gaza is caused by four man-made factors: conflict, displacement, restricted access, and food system collapse.

Israel imposed a total blockade on the entry of food and other supplies into Gaza in mid-March, just before it unilaterally broke a ceasefire that had held since January. Severe restrictions on imports to Gaza remain in place, and Israel’s insistence that it will continue fighting has contributed to the spread of the famine.

01:18
Israel’s genocide in Gaza: Famine takes its toll on mothers and infants
22h ago (11:00 GMT)
‘A message from Gaza, from the middle of genocide’

A Palestinian in Gaza, Mohannad al-Khateeb, has shared a message of support with the Sumud flotilla, thanking them for their journey.

“This is a message from Gaza from the middle of genocide,” al-Khateeb said in a video filmed on the beach in Gaza and shared on social media.

“We are with you and we are standing with you and our hearts are with you. Please be careful and stay safe and I hope you will arrive safely.”
23h ago (10:30 GMT)
Greta Thunberg: Celebrated climate activist who has used her clout to support Gaza

The 22-year-old Swedish climate icon is perhaps the most famous name on the Sumud Flotilla, having risen to prominence in 2018 when she began a school strike movement in her home country to demand action to stop climate change.

Thunberg quickly gained prominence, addressing the United Nations and being named the youngest ever “Person of the Year” by Time magazine in 2019.

But elite circles have not been as vocal in their backing of Thunberg since she started voicing her support for Palestinians following the start of Israel’s war on Gaza, and she has faced criticism from some on the pro-Israeli side.

Thunberg has, however, doubled down on her pro-Palestinian activism, and joined a flotilla seeking to break Israel’s siege of Gaza in June. The Madleen ship she was travelling on was eventually violently intercepted by Israeli forces, and Thunberg, along with the others on board, was briefly detained by Israel before being deported.

What happened to past Freedom Flotillas?

Several Freedom Flotilla vessels have attempted to break the blockade of Gaza.

Two boats from the Free Gaza Movement successfully reached Gaza in 2008. It was the first breach of Israel’s naval blockade.

The movement, founded in 2006 by activists during Israel’s war on Lebanon, went on to launch 31 boats between 2008 and 2016, five of which reached Gaza despite heavy Israeli restrictions.

But since 2010, all flotillas attempting to break the Gaza blockade have been illegally intercepted or attacked by Israel in international waters.

In 2010, Israeli commandos raided the Mavi Marmara in international waters, killing 10 activists and injuring dozens, leading to global outrage.

The ship was carrying humanitarian aid and more than 600 passengers.

In July 2025, the Handala was intercepted in the Mediterranean Sea.

People wake up, and preparations and training sessions are promised for after breakfast.

Then comes the crucial training: how to respond to a possible interception in international waters by the Israeli army and the boarding of the ship.

The volunteers recall their sessions on non-violence back in Barcelona – never engaging with Israeli soldiers, never touching them in any way, and always keeping their hands visible.

Any break from the non-violent nature of the mission could cost someone their life.

Famine declared in Gaza in August

The UN-backed Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) determined that there was famine in Gaza City and other areas of northern Gaza in August, warning that it would spread to other parts of the Palestinian enclave by September if Israel’s war did not end.

The famine has given added urgency to the Global Sumud Flotilla’s mission to break the siege of Gaza.

The IPC said that the famine in Gaza is caused by four man-made factors: conflict, displacement, restricted access, and food system collapse.

Israel imposed a total blockade on the entry of food and other supplies into Gaza in mid-March, just before it unilaterally broke a ceasefire that had held since January. Severe restrictions on imports to Gaza remain in place, and Israel’s insistence that it will continue fighting has contributed to the spread of the famine.

01:18
Israel’s genocide in Gaza: Famine takes its toll on mothers and infants
22h ago (11:00 GMT)
‘A message from Gaza, from the middle of genocide’

A Palestinian in Gaza, Mohannad al-Khateeb, has shared a message of support with the Sumud flotilla, thanking them for their journey.

“This is a message from Gaza from the middle of genocide,” al-Khateeb said in a video filmed on the beach in Gaza and shared on social media.

“We are with you and we are standing with you and our hearts are with you. Please be careful and stay safe and I hope you will arrive safely.”
23h ago (10:30 GMT)
Greta Thunberg: Celebrated climate activist who has used her clout to support Gaza

The 22-year-old Swedish climate icon is perhaps the most famous name on the Sumud Flotilla, having risen to prominence in 2018 when she began a school strike movement in her home country to demand action to stop climate change.

Thunberg quickly gained prominence, addressing the United Nations and being named the youngest ever “Person of the Year” by Time magazine in 2019.

But elite circles have not been as vocal in their backing of Thunberg since she started voicing her support for Palestinians following the start of Israel’s war on Gaza, and she has faced criticism from some on the pro-Israeli side.

Thunberg has, however, doubled down on her pro-Palestinian activism, and joined a flotilla seeking to break Israel’s siege of Gaza in June. The Madleen ship she was travelling on was eventually violently intercepted by Israeli forces, and Thunberg, along with the others on board, was briefly detained by Israel before being deported.

That has not stopped Thunberg from participating in the latest – and much bigger – flotilla as one of its organisers.
Swedish campaigner Greta Thunberg talks to journalists upon her arrival to Roissy-Charles de Gaulle Airport, as she left Israel on a flight to Sweden via France, after she was detained along with other activists aboard a Gaza-bound aid boat, on June 10, 2025.

23h ago (10:00 GMT)
UN expert says flotilla ‘fully complies with international law’

Francesca Albanese, the UN special rapporteur on the occupied Palestinian territory, has shared a message of support to the Sumud crew, saying their mission “fully complies with international law”.

“Any attempt to intercept and stop the flotilla on its way to Gaza might constitute an aggression and a violation of the crew’s rights under international maritime law,” Albanese said in a video message shared on social media. “Together we must break the siege.”
U.N. Special Rapporteur for the Occupied Palestinian Territories Francesca Albanese talks to The Associated Press at the Sarajevo airport in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Thursday, July 10, 2025, on her way to events commemorating the 30th anniversary of the Srebrenica genocide. (AP Photo/Darko Bandic)
Albanese is an independent human rights expert appointed by the UN Human Rights Council [File: Darko Bandic/AP Photo]
24h ago (09:30 GMT)
Politicians back Global Sumud Flotilla mission

Numerous leaders, public figures and international organisations have expressed their support for the Global Sumud Flotilla and its mission to break Gaza’s siege.

Colombia’s President Gustavo Petro wrote to the activists onboard the flotilla expressing his solidarity and support for their mission.

 

In Italy, former Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte, the head of the country’s Five Star Movement, described the Global Sumud Flotilla as an “extraordinary reaction from ‘below’ to international indifference” on the topic.

As well as Barcelona’s former mayor, Ada Colau, who is on board the flotilla, a number of Spanish politicians have expressed their support. Jaume Asens, a Spanish member of the European Parliament, has written in support of the flotilla, while Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Albares said his government will “deploy all of its diplomatic and consular protection to protect our citizens” sailing towards Gaza.
3 Sep 2025 - 08:30 (08:30 GMT)
Mandela’s grandson part of South Africa’s flotilla delegation

Nkosi Zwelivelile “Mandla” Mandela, grandson of Nelson Mandela, will be one of 10 South Africans sailing with the Sumud Flotilla, which he says is responding to the threat posed by “apartheid Israel and Netanyahu and his regime”.

Speaking at a rally in Johannesburg before departing, Mandela said the convoy is bringing “humanitarian aid that is much needed to the Palestinians”.

“Many have seen for yourselves that a million people in Gaza are being starved to death,” he said. “We are proud comrades to say that we have over 40 boats that we have been able to mobilise with 44 countries that have come together.”

‘Not just symbolic’: Tadhg Hickey

Irish comedian, filmmaker, and Global Sumud Flotilla activist Tadhg Hickey spoke to Al Jazeera on Sunday about his reasons for participating in trying to break Israel’s siege on the people of Gaza.

'Not just symbolic, flotilla to Gaza aims to break Israel’s illegal siege': Tadhg Hickey
3 Sep 2025 - 06:30 (06:30 GMT)
Explainer
Which countries are participating in the Sumud Flotilla?

According to the Global Sumud Flotilla, delegations from 44 countries have already committed to sail to Gaza as part of the largest maritime mission attempting to break Israel’s illegal siege of the Palestinian territory.

People from six continents will be taking part in the flotilla, including from countries such as Australia, Brazil, South Africa and numerous European states.

3 Sep 2025 - 05:30 (05:30 GMT)
Elected representatives on board call for ‘immediate humanitarian corridor’

Twelve elected representatives taking part in the Sumud Flotilla issued a statement on Wednesday calling for “immediate action to ensure humanitarian access to Gaza”.

“We call on all states and relevant authorities to take every possible measure to guarantee, at a minimum, the opening of a safe and continuous humanitarian corridor to Gaza,” the signatories said.

“This is a moral, legal, and humanitarian imperative,” they added. “Civilians must have access to life-saving aid without obstruction or delay.”

The elected representatives on board the flotilla included politicians from Argentina, Brazil, Poland, Portugal, Spain and Sweden.

More than 160 other elected representatives also signed the statement in support of those on board.
Former Barcelona mayor Ada Colau reacts after delivering a speech at the launch of a civilian flotilla aimed at breaking the Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip, in Barcelona, on August 31, 2025.
Former Barcelona mayor Ada Colau, one of the signatories, speaks before the launch of the Sumud flotilla, in Barcelona, Spain on Sunday [AFP]
3 Sep 2025 - 04:30 (04:30 GMT)
Israel’s Ben-Gvir wants to designate flotilla volunteers as ‘terrorists’

Israeli National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir says he wants to designate all the Sumud Global Flotilla volunteers as “terrorists” and arrest them.

Ben-Gvir presented the plan at a discussion on Sunday to discuss measures to stop the flotilla from reaching the two million or so people trapped and starving in Gaza.

Attending the meeting were Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Defence Minister Israel Katz, Foreign Minister Gideon Saar, and Strategic Affairs Minister Ron Dermer.

Under Ben-Gvir’s suggestion, any volunteers taken while trying to bring food and aid into Gaza will be held in Israel’s Ketziot and Damon prisons, which are used to hold “terrorists” under stringent conditions typically reserved for security prisoners.

“We will not allow individuals who support terrorism to live in comfort. They will face the full consequences of their actions,” Ben-Gvir, who was convicted of inciting terrorism in 2007, said.

3 Sep 2025 - 03:30 (03:30 GMT)
Images: Global Sumud Flotilla leaving Barcelona

By Al Jazeera Staff

After delays due to weather, vessels taking part in the Global Sumud Flotilla set sail from Barcelona on Monday.

On board the vessels, along with Greta Thunberg, humanitarian activist Thiago Avila and roughly 350 other activists, is journalist and photographer Mauricio Morales, who will be reporting for Al Jazeera from one of the ships, the Alma.

Activists from 44 countries, including journalists, politicians, environmentalists, doctors and humanitarians had either used the extra time granted by the delay to either rest on board, or source additional supplies for Gaza, Morales said.

“Morale remained high, but uncertainty lingered about the exact departure time and whether a shifting political situation might delay or even block the flotilla’s exit from Barcelona,” Morales wrote from on board the Alma. “Sabotage was considered a real risk, and organisers were cautious about sharing sensitive information, wary of individuals seen filming the boats and crews.”

3 Sep 2025 - 02:30 (02:30 GMT)
‘We will not be stopped,’ says Northern Irish activist

“I am here just like every other person on this global flotilla to bring aid, medical aid, and to bring food and hope and solidarity to the people of Palestine,” said Fra Hughes, the 62-year-old Northern Irish director of the charity Palestine Aid, from on board the Alma.

“We go on the marches and we sing ‘we see you, we hear you’, but not only do we see you and hear you, we are coming to you,” he added.

“I expect this flotilla under the international rules to be allowed to go to Gaza. That’s our plan. We stand with the people of Palestine and we will not be stopped.”

3 Sep 2025 - 01:25 (01:25 GMT)
Italian humanitarian organisation to join flotilla

The Italian humanitarian organisation EMERGENCY has announced that its search and rescue ship, called Life Support, will join the Sumud Flotilla as an observer.

Life Support will also provide medical and logistical support to the other vessels in the flotilla, EMERGENCY said in a statement.

“What is happening in Gaza is unacceptable,” the aid group said. “Our staff, who work in two health clinics in the Khan Younis governorate, report an extremely grave situation.”

Life Support will set sail from Catania, alongside other vessels in the Italian delegation, EMERGENCY added.
2 Sep 2025 - 23:30 (23:30 GMT)
Drones spotted above Sumud Flotilla

By Mauricio Morales

Reporting from on board the Alma, off the Mediterranean coast of Spain

The rough weather that plagued the start of the Sumud Flotilla’s journey lingered into Tuesday morning, leaving some of the 24 volunteers on the Alma seasick. Exhausted, some volunteers found whatever corner they could to rest, even on the floor of the vessel, which was never designed to carry so many passengers.

The organisers of the flotilla assessed the damage after the storm, and instructed the vessels to regroup on a new course. Some boats had sustained damage, but have still been able to sail.

Daily life at sea quickly mixed political talks with chores: cleaning toilets, cooking, securing cargo, checking medical supplies, and rotating through security guard duty while discussing the political motives or the question that begins to resonate: “Why are you here?”

When the dark of the night began to settle to mark the end of the day, the Alma alarm blared, and everybody scrambled to the deck and put on their life jackets.

Two drones were hovering above the vessel, and communications from other boats reported the drones, as well. With the boat’s lights turned off, the flickering lights of the drones could be seen hovering over the vessel, before they eventually left, leaving those on the Alma silent, and wary.

2 Sep 2025 - 21:30 (21:30 GMT)
Analysis
‘The path ahead won’t be easy’: Head of French contingent

By Al Jazeera Staff
64 year old Franco-Tunisia Brahim Marzouk aboard the Sumud Flotilla [Courtesy of Brahim Marzouk]
Sixty-four-year-old French Tunisian Brahim Marzouk on board the Sumud flotilla [Courtesy of Brahim Marzouk]

Father of six Franco-Tunisian Brahim Marzouk, 64, is leading the flotilla’s French contingent on board the Alma.

“I’m completely involved in it,” he told Al Jazeera from on board the flotilla, “because it’s not just about Gaza, it’s about humanity.

“Let’s be clear, the path ahead [for the Flotilla] will not be easy. During our journey, we will meet many, many difficulties,” he said of the storms the flotilla had encountered.

“Gaza is living this every day. Every day they have many difficulties. I would say, incomparable to the difficulties that we are experiencing.”
2 Sep 2025 - 19:30 (19:30 GMT)
‘All of humanity is at stake’: Former mayor of Barcelona
Ada Colau Ballano, activist and former mayor of Barcelona
Ada Colau Ballano, activist and former mayor of Barcelona [Screengrab: Al Jazeera]

On board the Familia setting off from Barcelona is Ada Colau Ballano, an activist and the former mayor of the city of Barcelona from 2015 to 2023. She is the first woman to have held the position of Barcelona’s mayor.

Colau Ballano previously took part in a 2014 flotilla from Istanbul that Israel intercepted.

“What’s wonderful is that this time, from my own city, Barcelona, the biggest attempt of all is setting out with 20 boats, and it’s going to be very difficult for [Israel] to stop us from reaching Gaza,” she told Al Jazeera.

Colau Ballano was seen hugging her children and saying goodbye before setting sail.

“My children and I have always spoken very openly about how the world is, and we’ve talked about what’s happening in Gaza and in Palestine, and it’s something that is part of our daily life at home, so they’re very aware,” she said.

“My little one started to cry when he saw I was really getting on the boat, but he perfectly understands the reasons,” Colau Ballano said.

“He knows that thousands of boys and girls are being killed and that today it’s for them, tomorrow it will be for others, but we can’t allow it and so my children encouraged me to get on the flotilla, even though they may worry about me a little, but they encouraged me to go because they know what’s at stake and they totally support the cause.”
Ada Colau Ballano hugging her son goodbye on board the Familia
Colau Ballano hugs her son goodbye on board the Familia on August 31, 2025 [Mauricio Morales/Al Jazeera]
2 Sep 2025 - 17:30 (17:30 GMT)
What happened to past Freedom Flotillas?

Several Freedom Flotilla vessels have attempted to break the blockade of Gaza.

Two boats from the Free Gaza Movement successfully reached Gaza in 2008. It was the first breach of Israel’s naval blockade.

The movement, founded in 2006 by activists during Israel’s war on Lebanon, went on to launch 31 boats between 2008 and 2016, five of which reached Gaza despite heavy Israeli restrictions.

But since 2010, all flotillas attempting to break the Gaza blockade have been illegally intercepted or attacked by Israel in international waters.

In 2010, Israeli commandos raided the Mavi Marmara in international waters, killing 10 activists and injuring dozens, leading to global outrage.

The ship was carrying humanitarian aid and more than 600 passengers.

In July 2025, the Handala was intercepted in the Mediterranean Sea.

Read more here.
2 Sep 2025 - 15:30 (15:30 GMT)
Genoa port workers threaten lockdown if Israel harasses Flotilla

On Saturday, port workers from Genoa, Italy, issued a stark challenge to Israeli authorities should they attempt to intercept the flotilla, as they have previous ones.

“Around mid-September, these boats will arrive near the coast of Gaza. If we lose contact with our boats, with our comrades, even for just 20 minutes, we will shut down all of Europe,” an unidentified dockworker from the Unione Sindacale di Base Confederazione Nazionale (USB) told crowds over the weekend in a widely circulated video.

“From this region 13 to 14,000 containers leave every year for Israel, not a single nail will leave anymore,” he added.
2 Sep 2025 - 13:30 (13:30 GMT)
Everything you need to know about the Flotilla

The Global Sumud Flotilla for Gaza has set out towards Gaza after a false start on Sunday.

Hundreds of people are on board about 15 vessels, including journalists, doctors, politicians, humanitarians and activists from 44 countries.

The flotilla’s planned first stop is Tunisia, where they will link up with other ships.

They will be joined by more boats from Italy and other undisclosed ports in an effort to break Israel’s illegal siege on Gaza, which is starving Palestinians to death as Israel’s war on Gaza continues.

The volunteers hope to transport much-needed food and medicine to besieged Palestinians and to open a humanitarian corridor, allowing more civilian vessels to follow.

This is the largest effort to break Israel’s siege on Gaza and follows previous attempts dating back to 2010. Israel intercepted and sometimes attacked past flotillas.

Everything you need to know about the flotilla is explained here.
2 Sep 2025 - 13:15 (13:15 GMT)
‘It’s not about us, it’s about Gaza’

Before departing from Barcelona on Sunday, hundreds of volunteers on the Sumud Flotilla stressed that the “news story” is not them, but the hundreds of thousands of people dying from Israel’s genocide in Gaza.

“We are not heroes. We are not the story. The story is about the people of Gaza,” said Thiago Avila, a lifelong activist for Palestine and an organiser for the flotilla.

Many others on board the Flotilla echoed that sentiment and stressed that they were compelled to join the flotilla due to the distressing and horrific images of Palestinian children being relentlessly killed and starved to death.

“I love my daughter so much, as the mothers and fathers in Gaza [love their children], and because of this love. We cannot leave a world like this,” said Avila.

“We have to change the society that enables a genocide to happen,” he told Al Jazeera.

Read more here.
2 Sep 2025 - 12:49 (12:49 GMT)
Sumud Flotilla perseveres, departs Barcelona despite bad weather

By Al Jazeera Staff

The Global Sumud Flotilla has departed Barcelona on Monday evening after having had to return to port on Sunday due to bad weather.

Conditions are still far from ideal, with six of the smaller vessels already having had to return to port for repairs.

However, dozens of vessels remain, each carrying desperately needed aid for the blockaded Gaza Strip along with about 350 activists.

Russia has flatly rejected the prospect of any talks that consider the deployment of foreign troops in Ukraine.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman Maria Zakharova said on Wednesday that Moscow would not entertain discussion of an international post-conflict security force “in any format”.

“Russia is not going to discuss the fundamentally unacceptable and security-undermining foreign intervention in Ukraine in any form, in any format,” Zakharova told reporters on the sidelines of the Eastern Economic Forum in Vladivostok.

Zakharova said that European leaders, who are working on plans for a multinational force in the event of an agreement to end the war in Ukraine, should take note that the “next time they aim to discuss this topic, they should have a pointer in the form of Russia’s position”.

“Judging by Ukraine’s losses, the European Commission has simply outdone itself,” she said.

Zakharova made her comments after European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen told The Financial Times earlier this week that the European Union had “pretty precise plans” for deploying a multinational force to Ukraine.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and European leaders are set to meet in Paris on Thursday to firm up details of post-conflict security guarantees for Kyiv.

On Wednesday, French President Emmanuel Macron said the details of the security guarantees for Ukraine had been worked out but remained “extremely confidential”.

“We are ready, we the Europeans, to offer the security guarantees to Ukraine and Ukrainians the day that a peace [accord] is signed,” Macron said.

Despite United States President Donald Trump’s pledge to bring a swift end to the conflict, Moscow and Kyiv remain far apart on the terms of any potential peace agreement.
Russia has said that any deal with Ukraine would need to include land in four regions it has annexed since 2022, while Kyiv has ruled out ceding any territory.

Trump is scheduled to speak with Zelenskyy by phone on Thursday, and has said he intends to speak to Putin in the coming days.
summary:
Russia has categorically rejected any discussions about the post-war deployment of foreign troops or international security forces in Ukraine. Speaking at the Eastern Economic Forum in Vladivostok, Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova asserted that Moscow considers any foreign intervention in Ukraine “fundamentally unacceptable,” and would refuse to engage in talks on this issue in any context or format.

Her statement comes in response to recent remarks by European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, who indicated that the EU has detailed plans for sending a multinational force to Ukraine in the event of a peace deal. European leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron, are preparing to offer Ukraine comprehensive security guarantees, with details reportedly kept confidential for now.

Meanwhile, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and EU officials are set to meet in Paris to discuss these potential security arrangements. Zakharova criticized these European efforts, referencing Ukraine’s heavy losses and warning the EU to pay attention to Russia’s uncompromising position on the issue.

Although US President Donald Trump has pledged to bring a quick end to the conflict, Russia and Ukraine remain far apart on a potential resolution. Moscow insists on any peace agreement including recognition of Russian claims to four annexed regions, while Kyiv refuses to cede any territory. Trump is expected to speak with both Zelenskyy and Russian President Vladimir Putin in an attempt to move diplomacy forward.
